SDES1111 Integrated Design Computing 1 introduces students to the fundamentals of design computing for image processing and drawing. The course begins with 2D computing, including co-ordinate systems, basic coding and the introduction to commerical software applications. This lays a foundation for students to integrate manual and digital design knowledge and skills. In this course students will learn to explore, select and apply appropriate computing tools, processes and formats to the creative research, visualisation, manipulation, specification and presentation of original design ideas in a professional manner.

course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES1211 - Integrated Design Computing 2","description":"

SDES1211 Integrated Design Computing 2 introduces students to the fundamentals of design computing for digital objects and three-dimensional drawing. The course begins with 3D computing, including co-ordinate systems, basic coding and the introduction to commercial software applications. This lays a foundation for students to integrate manual and digital design knowledge and skills. In this course students will explore, select and apply appropriate computing tools, processes and formats to creative research, visualisation, manipulation, specification and presentation of original design ideas in a professional manner.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"4a4fb0ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ec","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Life Hacks: 3d Printing and the Everyday","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

For this assignment you are asked to ideate, design and manufacture an object or objects that connect the CAD (Computer Aided Design) territory to the physical world. Things that are designed in the digital domain, but infiltrate, augment or improve reality. The outcome is a 3D printed object designed on a computer that forms a connection to existing objects in the real world. You can solve a problem, fix the broken, beautify the ordinary, dress the naked, improve the imperfect, join the parted, and so on. 

For instance a customised connector to merge two existing objects in an innovative and creative way to unlock their combined potential. A few very basic examples would be a lamp shade for an existing lamp , a replacement or improvement part for a consumer good, a wearable object, ornament or piece of jewellery, home improvement object/gadget, a specialised tool, a toy with moving parts, a custom camera mount, a connection for your phone to your bike handlebar or speaker to your shelf. Be ambitious with your ideas. 

Important is you quantify reality first, by taking precise measurements of your chosen existing object(s) to be able to customise your design, so it forms a functional and durable attachment, joint or coupling. You are encouraged to design and manufacture functional objects, with working hinges, mechanical clamps, locking mechanism that have a real world use and practical application. Consider the clearance required for a functional and reliable mechanical fit.

Research and problem solving is part of this assignment. You will learn the basic principles of CAD design and learn the digital tools and techniques required, but each project is different and you will need to demonstrate the ability for independent inquiry. Designing and manufacturing for the real world is an iterative process, be prepared to experiment and try multiple approaches and document your process and progress as this is an important part of this assignment.

Coursework tutorials will support you in the completion of this assessment task, and the skills you gain through this project form a foundation for later studio studies in the Bachelor of Design Degree.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"024fb0ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619e6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"4e4fb0ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619e8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c24fb0ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619e3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3d4fb0ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"3D Modelling and Design: Object Dialogues.","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

Your task is to conceive, design and create a 3D computer model of an emotional and/or poetic dialogue between two objects in an interior setting. The design must illustrate the object interaction, building the emotional connection between the objects in an imaginative way. The objects may exist separately or be combined. The symbolic dialogue should be achieved by using design elements and principles, for example colour, scale, shape dynamics, deformation, texture, etc. Technically, the aim of this project is to create a realistic computer model of objects, to use lighting and texture maps to develop realistic rendered object visualisations and to improve 3D modelling and design presentation skills. It is recommended that you select simple domestic objects.

Coursework tutorials will support you in the completion of this assessment task, and the skills you gain through this project form a foundation for later studio studies in the Bachelor of Design Degree.

contentlets.keywords: design studies,computer aided drafting,3d modelling,parametric models
contentlets.description: SDES1211 Integrated Design Computing 2 introduces students to the fundamentals of design computing for digital objects and three-dimensional drawing. The course begins with 3D computing, including co-ordinate systems, basic coding and the introduction to commercial software applications. This lays a foundation for students to integrate manual and digital design knowledge and skills. In this course students will explore, select and apply appropriate computing tools, processes and formats to creative research, visualisation, manipulation, specification and presentation of original design ideas in a professional manner.
contentlets.title: Integrated Design Computing 2

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES2116 - Design Practice","description":"

Design Practice helps you develop an understanding of the many contexts in which design can be practiced.  Exploration of design practice includes the intersection of theoretical and practitioner perspectives using a weekly set of industry encounters, guest lectures and video vignettes. You will develop a plan for a digital personal profile that has the capacity to communicate effectively with a range of external design practitioners, sites and situations.  This course will prepare you to effectively undertake professional experience projects (PEP) and create new pathways in design practice.


 


In this course you will investigate key themes in design practice contexts including:


 


·       Introduction to design practice


·       A day in the life of a designer


·       Structure and scale


·       Transition design


·       Compliance and constraints


·       Intellectual property (IP)


·       Professional communication, collaboration and delegation


·       Dilemmas and challenges in professional practice


·       Branding (Business)


·       Branding (Personal)


·       Adaptation and reflection


Through a series of tutorials, activities and assessments you will analyse case studies of current and emerging modes of design practice; research and interview design practitioners and develop a plan for your future professional career.  You will explore and reflect on the impact of ethical, financial, intellectual and social constraints on design practice and discover the essential role of communication and collaboration in sustainable practice.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"313f30ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961940","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Design Practice SWOT Case Studies","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, Threats (SWOT) analysis on three different design practices.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"a93f30ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961936","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e53f30ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961939","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5d3f30ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961914","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research interview and reflection","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

Part A: Research interview conducted in a group of 3.

Part B: Individual written analysis and reflection

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"253f30ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96193c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"a93f30ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961936","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e53f30ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961939","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"953f30ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961919","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"5 Year Professional Development Plan","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

A self-reflection on your current situation as a design professional including:

A statement on what you learned from the “Industry Encounters Video Series” as applied to your personal practice;

An overview of your personal career goals including a “mission statement” that could be used on a professional design association website (see list below) to communicate professionally to stakeholders;

An outline of the knowledge, skills and experience that you wish to acquire against a realistic timeframe;

An action plan for (at least) the next five years, which outlines strategies and milestones for achieving your goals;

A range of broad strategies that you will use to maintain currency of knowledge and skills in your chosen design discipline area.

The course provides an introduction to textiles, explored in the context of Fashion. The course covers the design of textiles for the fashion, apparel and accessories industry. Particular emphasis will be placed on the textiles used, the selection of fabrics, the sustainable nature of materials and the manipulation of the textile surface for fashion garments. It will also cover the work of selected designers, investigating how they incorporate specific textile techniques into their fashion ranges. The course will focus on design as a process, ways of interpreting trend inspirations and will culminate in a final textile surface design / print collection. You will design their own textile collection based on research into current market and fashion trends, applying these influences to the design process.

Examine an internationally recognised fashion label with the intention of designing a directional range of textile designs referencing the signature design style of your chosen label, and simultaneously express in your own handwriting.

\n","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"25fe6dfbdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961926","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2dfe6dfbdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961944","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"15fe6dfbdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961918","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Transforming a Scarf","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

Fashion history reveals a long lineage of ever-changing trends, often reflecting influences from historical or cultural sources, which are constantly being recycled and reinvented for new eras. You are to examine examples of this throughout fashion history, in order to inform your own unique designs.

\n","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"25fe6dfbdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961926","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2dfe6dfbdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961944","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"69fe6dfbdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961947","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"edfe6dfbdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961941","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5dfe6dfbdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96191c","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SDES2167.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"SDES2168","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES2168 - Commercial Textile Design","description":"

This course follows the design process for the commercial production of textiles, from design brief and concept development to sampling and final manufacture. By tracking the evolution of a textile design from sketch, design brief, concept development, colour separation and printing onto fabric, you will develop your own designs for textiles. The course covers design for weave, stitch and print processes at studio and industry level, including professional presentation, colour ways and client requirements. The course will cover social, environmental and cultural influences that impact on design trends, forecasting and contemporary design. The topics covered include the evolution of textile design, historical and cultural techniques for patterning cloth such as block printing and tapestry weaving; techniques used commercially including screen printing, roller printing and loom weaving; and the current emphasis on digital design development and direct digital printing onto fabric. The course includes number of industry studio visits where you will meet textile designers working in the fashion, home ware and interior design sectors who will explain concept, briefs, design development and client relationships. These designers will show you their studios, discuss current projects and share sources of inspiration and ways of working. These visits offer an excellent insight into career possibilities in textile design. This course and industry knowledge can be incorporated into to project work so that you understand the industry requirements, and experience responding to industry standard briefs for contemporary textile ranges. 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"7c41c537db391c50eb6b147a3a961950","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Contemporary Australian Textiles","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Research one contemporary Australian textile artist / designers / company and their use of florals in their collections. Present as a written analysis of their design practise along with visuals. A list of suggested designers and companies is available in the Task 1 outline. Task 1 should be at least 1000 words and include a bibliography, correct referencing and acknowledgement of all sources, images and quotes.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3441c537db391c50eb6b147a3a96194a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"7041c537db391c50eb6b147a3a96194d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a841c537db391c50eb6b147a3a961925","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"The Natural World - Concept Board","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Conduct research into a culture/region where references to the natural world are featured in the textiles. Presented as a written analysis together with a visual concept board. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3441c537db391c50eb6b147a3a96194a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"7041c537db391c50eb6b147a3a96194d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b841c537db391c50eb6b147a3a961944","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f441c537db391c50eb6b147a3a961947","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e041c537db391c50eb6b147a3a96192a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"The Natural World - Textile Design Collection","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Inspired by your previous research and concept developments develop a commercial textile design collection based on the theme of the natural world. Considering colour trends, pattern, form and fabric. Present a series of 4 designs and a written concept statement (max 200 words).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b841c537db391c50eb6b147a3a961944","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f441c537db391c50eb6b147a3a961947","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e041c537db391c50eb6b147a3a96193b","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SDES2168.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

honours).","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"SDES2184","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES2184 - Textiles: Woven Forms","description":"

This course covers the textile processes and techniques of woven, interlaced and constructed textiles with practical projects in tapestry, basketry, 3d interlacing and loom weaving. Weaving produces structures that can be used to make the finest of silk fabrics, define a shape or image in tapestry, create a texture or interlace any flexible material, metal or plastic to express a concept. Practical work in basketry, tapestry and loom weaving are complemented by historical, theoretical and conceptual references and information, providing an understanding of contemporary textile art and design practices involving woven structures.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"707fc6abdbf59850eb6b147a3a96199f","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Weaving: Matter Out of Place","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

This project allows you to explore the meanings inherent in materials, especially those not usually associated with woven forms, by weaving them into different contexts. It gives you the opportunity to develop a concept or refine one that already appears in your work. It is not necessary to use the concept of pollution or dirt in your project, merely that you consider how a material “means” in one situation, and re-contextualise it to provide alternative readings, or to emphasis one particular meaning.

This project asks that you consider the concept of 'Weaving matter out of place' as detailed in the project outline, to create a significant final woven piece or series that addresses this concept and your translation into either 2D or 3D woven forms (or a combination of 2D and 3D forms). Forms can be basketry or loom woven.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"387fc6abdbf59850eb6b147a3a961998","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"747fc6abdbf59850eb6b147a3a96199b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f47fc6abdbf59850eb6b147a3a961986","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f87fc6abdbf59850eb6b147a3a961995","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"207fc6abdbf59850eb6b147a3a96197d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Woven Forms: Investigations and Experimentations","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

This course begins with a series of studio and workshop sessions introducing a range of basketry, interlacing and weaving techniques for creating 2D and 3D forms. You will be introduced to a range of techniques, the fundamentals of interlacing, weaving equipment, appropriate materials and processes for creating woven forms. The workshops and experiments will extend your knowledge of basketry and weaving and its potential for individual, creative outcomes. 

To compliment and inform your practical explorations, you will be required to locate and investigate a unique contemporary woven textile / basketry artwork, object, textile or artifact from a current exhibition in a gallery or museum in Sydney. This piece should be a contemporary work but it may reference an historical item. The resulting research report is to include documentation of the selected piece through drawings/sketches, reflective writing, research and investigating its context. Report should describe the object, the artists concept for the art or design work, materials, processes and presentation. All images and academic resources are to be appropriately referenced.

honours).","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"SDES2188","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES2188 - Wheel Throwing in Contemporary Ceramic Practice","description":"

This course highlights a range of fundamental approaches and skills that underpin the multiple strands of contemporary ceramic practice. Practical work is contextualised within the historical and theoretical considerations/debates that frame contemporary ceramic practice. In particular, studio projects give prominence to ideas and processes associated with the development of ceramic multiples and work in series, using the wheel as the principal tool.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"ee518937db391c50eb6b147a3a9619ea","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project proposal and glaze fired works","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

In this project you will further develop the skills developed in Task 1 and apply these to a project proposal of your own choice that responds critically to examples of contemporary ceramics practice you have studied. Your project proposal should set out the ideas driving the work you wish to create, the techniques you will use to create it and describe the aesthetic characteristics necessary for it’s convincing realisation. The concept proposal will include reference images, a critical analysis of how research has informed your ideas, a concrete description of project aims (including number and shape of pieces described in sketches), and your strategy for execution - a 5 page A4 report style document submitted in class. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2a518937db391c50eb6b147a3a9619cb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"16518937db391c50eb6b147a3a9619ae","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Self Directed Studio project and reflective visual journal.","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Exhibit a range or set of glaze fired, wheel formed ceramic works that realise your self directed project. The works should be presented in a considered manner.

\n

Submission requirements Due: Week 14 in an exhibition context.

\n

Reflective Journal: Record your coursework progress in a single unruled journal. Document your research, ideas, testing processes, responses to workshop activities and class contributions. Include your research, art & design ideas, testing processes. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"66518937db391c50eb6b147a3a9619ce","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5e518937db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Throwing introductory exercises","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

This project will introduce you to the fundamental principals of wheel thrown pottery form. You will practice preparing clay and manipulating it on the pottery wheel over a period of time before creating a number of simple vessel shapes, and finish them in the green stage using appropriate turning techniques. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ea518937db391c50eb6b147a3a9619c8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"da518937db391c50eb6b147a3a9619a9","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SDES2188.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES2201 - Introduction to Furniture and Lighting Design","description":"

This course focuses on the skills and processes used in the design and fabrication of contemporary furniture and lighting. Students will be given the opportunity to select either furniture or lighting as the major driver for their skills development. The furniture design introduction will cover areas from forest to furniture sourcing and fabrication, solid timber, veneers, laminations, turning, and jointing techniques. The lighting design introduction will cover various contemporary light sources including Light Emitting Diodes (LEDS), and Plasma Lamps. Demonstrations will include discussion of lamp spectra, other lamp characteristics and how they contribute to a space. Attention will be given to the design and development of a sustainable practice in design by developing practical projects informed by integrating research, concepts and experimentation.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"07d174fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961953","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Forms and Finishes","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

Design a selected furniture piece or object that demonstrates appropriate use of materials, connection methods forms and finishes. Designs should demonstrate a proficiency in making and innovative design to the selected brief.


Written and verbal feedback. Reflective written peer review

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"0bd174fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a96194f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"76d174fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961915","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b2d174fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961918","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"fad174fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a96194c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6ad134fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619d5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Material Connections","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

Undertake research into a lighting design that inspires you. Thoroughly research the designer and their philosophy. From your research and recently acquired skills design and prototype a new light.  Students will be assessed on their skills and knowledge of specific equipment and materials relative to furniture and lighting design.


Written and verbal feedback and reflective peer review.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"0bd174fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a96194f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"76d174fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961915","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b2d174fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961918","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"fad174fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a96194c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b2d134fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619da","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SDES2201.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

contentlets.description: This course focuses on the skills and processes used in the design and fabrication of contemporary furniture and lighting. Students will be given the opportunity to select either furniture or lighting as the major driver for their skills development. The furniture design introduction will cover areas from forest to furniture sourcing and fabrication, solid timber, veneers, laminations, turning, and jointing techniques. The lighting design introduction will cover various contemporary light sources including Light Emitting Diodes (LEDS), and Plasma Lamps. Demonstrations will include discussion of lamp spectra, other lamp characteristics and how they contribute to a space. Attention will be given to the design and development of a sustainable practice in design by developing practical projects informed by integrating research, concepts and experimentation.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES2203 - Drawing for Design","description":"

Drawing is a critical tool for the design process, and is a must-have skill for design practitioners - even in today's highly computerised age. From analysing the client’s brief, developing a return brief, generating design concepts, communicating ideas with collaborators, to presenting possible solutions to the client, drawing is a simple but quick means that can significantly contribute to both design thinking and communication in the design process.  


Drawing for Design is designed to support essential design drawing skills through three studio projects focusing on observational drawing, visualisation drawing and presentation drawing.  You will explore the materials to test different drawing methods and purposes; study techniques and ways to generate and reflect on ideas; examine shape, form, surface and structure to question the aesthetics, appearance and functions of 2D & 3D objects; as well as de-construct / re-construct 2D & 3D design products to make visible design ideas and concepts. This course will support you to develop your own personalised drawing methods, and use them as an effective means to support your design thinking mapping and design communications.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"1b2bb837dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961945","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Drawing for Narrative and Representation","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

This assessment will further develop your sketching skills. It will integrate your drawing process your understanding of the basic rules of typology, and you will explore the meaning of affordance. Through the exercise of investigating a selected type of object from your daily life, your capacity of applying sketching skills in design practice both as record and analysis tools can be further enhanced. The final artworkds need to be properly organized and presented as an A3-size report with a cover page.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1f2bb837dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961941","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"db2bb837dbf51c50eb6b147a3a96192f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"df2bb837dbf51c50eb6b147a3a96193e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"072bb837dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961926","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Drawing for Recording, Investigation & Description","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

The assessment consists of two parts:

1. For Part one, you will explore various forms of drawings / sketches of selected precedents and their associations with different design practices in order to understand the general properties of drawings / sketches. This will also allow you to become more familiar with the essence of drawing in different design practices. This research work needs to be presented as an A4-size report with selected precedents’ drawing works and your reflective comments in about 500 words.

2. For Part two, you will study essential drawing skills using various media / techniques to observe, record and investigate targeted objects. In total, 16 A4-size or A3-size drawings / sketches are expected to be produced during and after studio class time.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1f2bb837dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961941","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"db2bb837dbf51c50eb6b147a3a96192f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"832bb837dbf51c50eb6b147a3a96191d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Drawing for Critical Thinking & Interpretation","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

In this assessment , you will develop your drawing forms and skills through thinking / mapping tools to process information resources, reorganize the key physical elements and investigate relevant design issues. 

Through deconstructing your selected 2D or 3D design works, the studio exercises will engage you in exploration from the figurative to the abstract, and from the abstract to the figurative. You will develop a set of drawings to effectively visualize the thinking and mapping process using your personal experiences for your selected design works. You must also include up to 300 words total as captions, notes or descriptions to support your drawings.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1f2bb837dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961941","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"db2bb837dbf51c50eb6b147a3a96192f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"cb2bb837dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961921","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SDES2203.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES2400 - Textiles, Design Narratives","description":"

SDES2400 Textile Design Narratives introduces you to the practice and processes of designing contemporary textiles. It covers the language, materials and conventions of textile design and how concepts, motif, colour and pattern impact on the narrative. It allows you to experiment with visual representation of your ideas; to research historical and contemporary precedents; and to create individual, one-off designs and design ranges that comply with industry conventions in their presentation. 


This course covers the design process by taking an idea from sketch form, developing it with specific drawing techniques to a 'croquis' form; converting this into a one off design, then into repeat and finally to developing a range of designs. By utilising both hand and digital technologies, the designs developed are situated within a specific sector / community. The course covers sustainable and environment concerns of the materials and processes used in this stage of textile design.


Assessment in this course includes researching textile design precedents and projects that engage with drawing, motif generation, individual and design ranges. 


SDES2400 Textile Design Narratives and SDES2401 Textile Pattern and Form are complementary 2nd year courses which together form the two x 2000 level core studies in the Textile Design studio stream within the BDes program. Together these courses prepare students for more advanced studies in the 3000 level courses in this studio stream. These courses may also be taken as an elective where places are available. 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"bb0f78bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c9","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 3: Make Your Mark: digital techniques","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

This project introduces CAD as a tool to create textile designs. The programs will include Adobe Photoshop, InDesign and Adobe Illustrator.

Design outcomes for this task are five resolved croquis (20x20cm) exploring a variety of mark-making techniques. They will be directed by the below design options – set tasks for 5 days each week for the next 2 weeks.

Group and peer studio discussions, individual studio consultation, written and verbal feedback. Feedback will be delivered via review on the Moodle site in a timely manner (no more than two weeks from the date of submission), be succinct and clear with personalized comments for each student. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"af0f78bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e70f78bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619bd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"130f78bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619a3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 4: The Fictional Flower","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

This project consolidates and expands upon skills learnt in Task 3 where CAD is a tool to create textile designs. The programs used will include Adobe Photoshop, Illustrator and InDesign.

Develop five repeat patterns using non-botanic imagery eg. hardware, body parts, buildings to create textile appropriate patterns with a Botanic theme. There are two ways that you can approach the Botanic theme.

Group and peer studio discussions, individual studio consultation, written and verbal feedback. Feedback will be delivered via review on the Moodle site in a timely manner (no more than two weeks from the date of submission), be succinct and clear with personalized comments for each student. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"630f78bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"af0f78bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e70f78bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619bd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"130f78bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 1: Make Your Mark: hand drawing techniques","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

This project introduces a range of hand drawing that can be employed in developing textile designs. It requires an immediate response to new and familiar mark-making techniques. You are required to be experimental and work to a professional level.

Botanics, being a common theme for textile design, will be the source of inspiration to generate five new and contemporary designs for fabric application.

Design outcomes for this task are five resolved croquis (20x20cm) exploring a variety of mark-making techniques, all directed by the design options below. Each croquis must be suitable for textile application and be inspired by the theme of Botanics.

Group and peer studio discussions, individual studio consultation, written and verbal feedback. Feedback will be delivered via review on the Moodle site in a timely manner (no more than two weeks from the date of submission), be succinct and clear with personalized comments for each student. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"630f78bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"af0f78bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e70f78bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619bd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9f0f78bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961999","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 2: The Hidden Narrative","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

This project explores the hidden stories found within fabrics. They may be historical, political, cultural, relevant to one person, or a community.

Through studio discussion we will look at textile practitioners who tell story through cloth, methods to embed cloth with narrative, and how a textile range can imply story.

The final outcome will be five croquis utilizing a variety of surface decoration techniques suitable for fabric driven by your concept. Highly resolved designs and an appropriate concept for the range is the required outcome.

Group and peer studio discussions, individual studio consultation, written and verbal feedback. Feedback will be delivered via review on the Moodle site in a timely manner (no more than two weeks from the date of submission), be succinct and clear with personalized comments for each student.

The course covers sustainable and environment concerns of the materials and processes used in this stage of textile design.

Assessment in this course includes researching textile design precedents and projects that engage with drawing, motif generation, individual and design ranges. 

SDES2400 Textile Design Narratives and SDES2401 Textile Pattern and Form are complementary 2nd year courses which together form the two x 2000 level core studies in the Textile Design studio stream within the BDes program. Together these courses prepare students for more advanced studies in the 3000 level courses in this studio stream. These courses may also be taken as an elective where places are available.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES2401 - Textiles, Pattern and Form","description":"

SDES2401 Textile Pattern and Form engages students in developing design solutions utilising 2D and 3D textile processes. The course introduces a range of surface patterning techniques and interlaced construction techniques. Briefs require designs to be generated for specific locations, communities and groups; with outcomes that involve the re-use, repurposing and recycling of materials; and that reflect the students interest in contemporary design. Workshops scheduled in this course are screenprinting and various basketry / interlacing techniques. 


The course includes technical information on material selection and specific processes; information on natural and man made materials; and with an emphasis on sustainable practices for textile design, the course covers sustainable and environment concerns of the materials and processes used for the techniques covered by the course. Assessment in this course includes researching precedents and projects that engage with screen printing, weaving and interlacing. 


SDES2401 Textile Pattern and Form and SDES2400 Textile Design Narratives are complementary 2nd year courses which together form the two x 2000 level core studies in the Textile Design studio stream within the BDes program. Together these courses prepare students for more advanced studies in the 3000 level courses in this studio stream. These courses may also be taken as an elective where places are available. 



","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e90f38bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b2","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Gene Visualisation","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

GENE VISUALISATION is a textile design project to produce a range of contemporary textiles utilising a variety of mark-making and textile techniques. The project requires design outcomes that visually and conceptually respond to patterns found within genes while fulfilling the project requirements as detailed in the project outline. The design outcomes will be a series of designs including one design screen printed in repeat. 

The project begins with research into genes, DNA and internal organ structures (Part 2.1) and a project proposal (Part 2.2) in response to the brief and including a concept statement, sketches and research into repeat patterns. 

The major component of Task 2 Gene Visualisation is the design range (Part 2.3) comprising four designs, one of which is screen printed in repeat and the other three designs realized in various textile surface design techniques; all designs need to be hand printed or hand made. The project will need to be documented in your journal and online in the GENE VISUALISATION blog (Part 2.4); with the final submission presented visually in a booklet, visually and verbally for the final presentation in studio in Week 14 (Part 2.5). 

This project will develop your knowledge and understanding of drawing, designing and image making for textiles. Directed by the brief and involving research, concept exploration, designing on paper, experimenting and designing with drawing and textile techniques and processes, the project requires a range of designs ideas.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"190f38bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619a6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"550f38bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619a9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"a10f38bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ac","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d90f38bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619a3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"ed0f38bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ae","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"090f38bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961968","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Interlaced: a contemporary textile design project","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

As a designer, you are asked to produce a contemporary textile design or range of designs that reflects the essence of Interlacing. Interlacing includes the textile techniques of coiling, plaiting, knotting and weaving while the term interlaced, can be applied to all forms of constructed textiles.

The Interlaced project begins with research into the patterns, structures, forms or character of interlacing techniques (Part 1.1). It involves selecting one historical or cultural basketry or woven interlaced forms or interlaced technique to research, investigate and document. The selected form or techniques could be from Australian indigenous, Asian or Pacific Island basketry, woven or interlaced techniques. Use this research to understand the cultural position of the selected interlaced form or technique, its role and position. The Interlaced extended project outline on SDES2401 Moodle site gives a list of objects, forms and techniques that could be selected. 

The major component of Task 1 Interlaced is to design, create and make a contemporary textile design or series of designs that reflects the essence of Interlacing. The first stage is to write a project proposal (Part 1.2) and then the final design or series of designs (Part 1.3). With the knowledge gained from lectures, workshops, exhibitions and your research, develop a project proposal (Part 1.2) that includes a historical or cultural reference, a concept statement, initial design(s), materials and / or processes involved. (Your contemporary designs do not necessarily have to reference the same historical or cultural object or technique described in your research but should have some historical or cultural reference).  

The final stage of the Interlaced project is to create, produce or make your contemporary design or series of designs (Part 1.3). The challenge of this project is for an innovative, contemporary design idea that incorporates interlacing presented in an experimental way. This project will develop your knowledge and understanding of researching, designing and making interlaced textiles. The final textile design or series of designs will include a concept statement, project documentation eg journal and blog (Part 1.4) and the presentation of Interlaced (Part 1.5) including a presentation booklet and verbal and visual presentation of the final design or series of designs.

This course explores our universal familiarity with textiles by engaging diverse approaches to working with cloth, fiber and thread within contemporary art practice. With a focus on conceptual development and experimentation with traditional and non-traditional materials and processes, you are asked to consider the multifaceted presence of textiles within the everyday and to develop an innovative approach to art making that integrates research, experimentation and concepts that engage your specific areas of interest. 


As part of the course you will be exposed to a range of traditional and non-traditional textile materials and techniques. You will engage in workshops that explore hand and machine stitching, bonded textiles, experimental and improvisational mark-making techniques, as well as the use of found and reclaimed objects and materials.


Assessment in this course includes research tasks, workshop experimentation and realising projects that engage with the concepts developed from this activity. Assessment will also include a studio journal to document the exploration of your ideas and reflections on research, technical and conceptual developments and the evaluation of your artworks. 


SDES2402 Textiles, Art and the Everyday and SDES2403 Textiles, Time and Memory are complementary 2nd year courses which together form the two x 2000 level core studies in the Textiles studio stream within the BFA program. These can also be taken as part of BMA. Together these courses prepare students for more advanced studies in the 3000 level courses in the Textiles stream. This course may also be taken as an elective where places are available.

This course explores the relationship between textiles, time and memory within contemporary art practice. You will develop strategies to work with and respond to objects held in collections and archives to extend research for contemporary art textiles practice. These repositories will be explored in their various forms and guises as a form of preserving, displaying and thinking about historical and culturally significant artifacts and their relationship to contemporary practice.


Cloth, textiles and related objects held within these collections will be researched for the archival and documentary qualities in conjunction with the related social, historical and cultural contexts in which it exists. The unique qualities of cloth as a carriage for time and memory will be investigated as creative platforms within current contemporary art practice.


Studio workshops will allow students to experiment in fabric dye and hand printing techniques. Through class lectures, readings and an excursion to a textile collection, students will be introduced to a range of local, international and digitized collections such as the MCA Library, Powerhouse Museum, Caroline Simpson Library & Research Collection, National Library of Australia and the Victoria & Albert Museum. 


Assessment in this course includes research tasks, workshop experimentation and realising projects that engage with the concepts developed from this activity. Assessment will also include a studio journal to document the exploration of your ideas and reflections on research, technical and conceptual developments and the evaluation of your artworks. 


SDES2403 Textiles, Time and Memory and SDES2402 Textiles, Art and the Everyday are complementary 2nd year courses which together form the two x 2000 level core studies in the Textiles studio stream within the BFA program. These can also be taken as part of BMA. Together these courses prepare students for more advanced studies in the 3000 level courses in the Textiles stream. This course may also be taken as an elective where places are available.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES2405 - Ceramics: Space, Structure and Surface","description":"

This course explores the personal and public contexts for ceramics, from the intimate character of domestic objects to the richness of pattern and scale in architecture. Lectures and studio workshops will introduce slip casting and press moulding processes, printed surface treatment, glazing and firing technologies to support your imaginative practice in the medium. 

You will undertake assessable studio research tasks, workshop activities and practical projects to create singular and serial objects that connect the material and psychological aspects of space, applying a knowledge of digital technologies to augment traditional methods relevant to the studio and industry.

The course encourages cross disciplinary thinking and activity, situating ceramics within Art, Design and Media studies. It is one of two interrelated Year 2 core courses that contribute to a four-course specialist Ceramics 'stream'. It may also be taken as an elective if spaces are available.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"3fee74bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961919","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Studio Project - Horror Vacui","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Horror Vacui’ is a theory derived from observations that in nature where empty spaces are readily occupied. First proposed by Aristotle in the Fourth book of Physics it refers to a fear of leaving empty space in a composition.For this assessment, you will develop and refine a body of slip cast ceramic work in a manner that responds to this theory while engaging space in creative and useful ways.

The submission of this assessment involvolves two key components, a concept proposal due in week 8. And,a body of work due in week 11. 

Concept proposals should include: a short conceptual description, sketches, short notes on significant research, no more than 2 precedent images and a timeline diagram showing key process milestones and dates for concept realisation. In addition to utilitarian considerations, your proposal should address the notion of Horror Vacui, associated with the site/space you are researching.  

The body of work should be presented in class along with your process journal and a 150 word explanatory statement outlining your ideas and processes. Upload to Moodle a single PDF. with this statement and a clear photograph of your body of work. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"33ee74bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961916","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f3ee74bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961913","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2bee34bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619fa","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research and Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

Research the work of a selected artist or designer working in the field of cast or moulded ceramics. Present a 4-minute talk with an illustrated powerpoint or PDF consisting of 5 pages with a minimum of 5 images.

Emphasis should be placed on contemporary practices where innovative strategies can be clearly identified. The talk and the powerpoint should be on the selected artist or designer's practice, articulating their aims, conceptual approach, technical processes and a critical review of an example of their work. You should cite at least ONE secondary source on their work. This could be a review, book, journal article or interview.  

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b7ee74bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961910","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a7ee34bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619f1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mapping Your Environment- Material and Process Investigations","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

In this project, you will explore set studio tasks to develop different aspects of studio practice in casting and mould-making.You are required to investigate aspects of a particular site or physical environment to inspire the creation of a series of ceramic works.The material and process based investigations you conduct for this assessment will be informed by your chosen site and the research you undertake of it.

You must  complete the individual tasks described below to present a minimum 6 fired and glazed ceramic works.The ceramic work described above must be presented, fired and glazed in a way that reflects the themes of your work.

Demonstrate glazing using brushwork, dipping and spraying.

  1. Model Making
  • Create a master for a plaster mould using clay.
  • Create a master for a plaster mould using a found object (this can include a 3D print).
  1. Plaster Mould making
  • Make a one part drop out plaster mould for a functional dish.
  • Make a two-part plaster mould.
  1. Slip Casting
  • Cast a series of 4 objects from your 1 part mould.
  • Cast and present a minimum of 2 objects from your two part mould.

This course explores the personal and public contexts for ceramics, from the intimate character of domestic objects to the richness of pattern and scale in architecture. Lectures and studio workshops will introduce slip casting and press moulding processes, printed surface treatment, glazing and firing technologies to support your imaginative practice in the medium. 

You will undertake assessable studio research tasks, workshop activities and practical projects to create singular and serial objects that connect the material and psychological aspects of space, applying a knowledge of digital technologies to augment traditional methods relevant to the studio and industry.

The course encourages cross disciplinary thinking and activity, situating ceramics within Art, Design and Media studies. It is one of two interrelated Year 2 core courses that contribute to a four-course specialist Ceramics 'stream'. It may also be taken as an elective if spaces are available.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES2406 - Graphics Media: Visual Communication","description":"

Graphics Media practice takes place in a wide range of contexts including; professional agencies, consultancies and scholarly enquiry. You are encouraged to critically reflect on historical precedents in studio practice and theory and their implications for current and future design directions. The course provides you with opportunities to investigate and explore: the field of visual communication design practice and scholarship; the roles of design and designers in the contexts of other disciplines; and how design functions in society. SDES2406 Graphic Communication explores the strategies and processes of Graphics Media design for a range of communities. You experiment with contemporary visual representation for print and screen media formats, and develop skills in documented observation as a research methodology for the design of hand generated and digitally manipulated images. Imaging techniques explored include illustration, collage and photomontage. Contexts considered for contemporary graphic communication range from the privacy of a book to public communication for out-door and web advertising.


Assessment in this course includes studio research tasks and projects that engage with image generation and composition, experimental book design and visual communication in the public arena.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a6ee34bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961921","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Experimental Book","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

Assessment 1 invites you to design a printed graphic studio-research book that interprets and extends original visual research documenting a selected community with which you are familiar, or connected to, 

The Experimental Book project is an opportunity to experiment with image generation (photography, illustration and/or collage, computational - Processing, generative), typography, a limited colour palette, texture, materials, formats, and production technologies.

Full details of the brief including specified deliverables, deadlines, submission process, and assessment rubric are provided as a design brief in the course. Verbal feedback is given during the studio project-based tutition and written summative feedback is provided via Review/Moodle.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1eee34bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961908","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5aee34bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96190b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"9aee34bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96191d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0eeef0bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619fa","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"The UNSW Piaggio Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

Assessment 2 invites you to engage in a 'real world' brief working with your peers and a client. The UNSW Piaggio Project is a design-led student project created in order to bring to life new interpretations of contemporary culture and lifestyles applied to one of the Piaggio company’s iconic brands - Vespa. 

Full details of the brief including specified deliverables, team work, deadlines, submission process, and assessment rubric are provided as a design brief in the course. Verbal feedback is given during the studio project-based tutition and written summative feedback is provided via Review/Moodle.

Note: The full detailed assessment brief for this task is in the course outline and on the course Moodle site.

Weighting for this assessment task is applied 50/50 to group and individual work.

contentlets.keywords: design studies,visual communication,graphic design,drawing,collage,photoshop,illustrator,photo manipulation
contentlets.description:
Graphics Media practice takes place in a wide range of contexts including; professional agencies, consultancies and scholarly enquiry. You are encouraged to critically reflect on historical precedents in studio practice and theory and their implications for current and future design directions. The course provides you with opportunities to investigate and explore: the field of visual communication design practice and scholarship; the roles of design and designers in the contexts of other disciplines; and how design functions in society. SDES2406 Graphic Communication explores the strategies and processes of Graphics Media design for a range of communities. You experiment with contemporary visual representation for print and screen media formats, and develop skills in documented observation as a research methodology for the design of hand generated and digitally manipulated images. Imaging techniques explored include illustration, collage and photomontage. Contexts considered for contemporary graphic communication range from the privacy of a book to public communication for out-door and web advertising.

Assessment in this course includes studio research tasks and projects that engage with image generation and composition, experimental book design and visual communication in the public arena.
contentlets.title: Graphics Media: Visual Communication

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES2407 - Graphics Media: Experimental Typography","description":"

SDES2407 Experimental Typography critically examines a range of graphic forms and how media experiences shape discussion, exchange and international understanding. You explore print, screen and online media production and consumption to develop typographic skills in designing and interpreting visual culture. Projects engage with the design of typography in a series of material experiments including traditional letterpress as well as industry software used in the layout of publications for print. This studio focuses on lettering, legibility, and typographic voice as well as grid design, type specification and reading hierarchy introduces experimental approaches to typography and publication design.

Assessment in this course includes studio research tasks and projects that engage with experimental typography and publication design for print.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"89eef0bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96194f","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Typographic Space","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

This project asks you to design new experimental typographic letterforms based on your initial research chronicling of all media that you have consumed in a one-week period, and deeper investigation of two specific media experiences using only typography. 

Your media experiences may include one or more of the following: text, email, social media, film, TV, radio, mobile phone encounters, or another identified in discussion with your studio tutor. Your development of a series of designs about media technologies provides you with the opportunity to consider how technological change impacts our experience of typographic design.

Informed by your design research process, fieldwork, and studio experimentation, in this project your design challenge is to consider and evaluate whether display typography is based in the visual conventions of image, or text, or both, and to develop an experimental typeface that responds to your findings.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"30eef0bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961937","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4deef0bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961939","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"8deef0bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96194b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"78eef0bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96191c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Publication Space","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

This project provides you with opportunities to develop an understanding of the conventions of publication design, conceptual approaches to media communication, and the technical vocabulary that describes page layout. You will design a cover, a contents page, and a two-page spread for a magazine of your own invention. The aim of the magazine is to attract a new audience to art and design.

contentlets.keywords: design studies,publication design,custom lettering,typeface design,experimental typography,indesign,illustrator
contentlets.description:
SDES2407 Experimental Typography critically examines a range of graphic forms and how media experiences shape discussion, exchange and international understanding. You explore print, screen and online media production and consumption to develop typographic skills in designing and interpreting visual culture. Projects engage with the design of typography in a series of material experiments including traditional letterpress as well as industry software used in the layout of publications for print. This studio focuses on lettering, legibility, and typographic voice as well as grid design, type specification and reading hierarchy introduces experimental approaches to typography and publication design.

Assessment in this course includes studio research tasks and projects that engage with experimental typography and publication design for print.
contentlets.title: Graphics Media: Experimental Typography

contentlets.keywords: design studies,jewellery fabrication,casting,design thinking,jewellery and object design
contentlets.description:
Jewellery Narratives, Concepts and Materials introduces students to the language of Jewellery and Object design through conceptual exploration, the acquisition of technical knowledge and studio based material investigations. Projects will employ a series of personal narratives and stories to explore and address stages of the design process, and implement critical analysis, research, problem-solving and design development culminating in the fabrication of finished jewellery design solutions. Communication techniques utilising two-dimensional and three-dimensional formats and basic computer skills will be developed.

Students will be presented with a series of lectures and demonstrations informing them of the different skills, knowledge and abilities required in order to undertake the creation of a three dimensional object.This course will develop students understanding of studio based jewellery practice through investigations of materials and jewellery processes. In practical terms students will examine the technology of metal and its translation through heat into three-dimensional forms.The techniques of soldering, casting and fabrication will be explored using non-ferrous metals, to translate design drawings and models into three-dimensional jewellery objects both wearable and non-wearable.

Assessment in this course is based on submission and evaluation of a three stage project development process including:

  1. Material investigations and conceptual studies
  2. Design proposal and statement examining possible solutions
  3. Narrative outcome evidenced in the final object presentation and documentation 

SDES2408 Jewellery Narratives, Concepts and Materialsis is an introductory 2000 level studio course. It is one of a suite of  two (or more) interrelated core courses in Year 2 that contribute to a four-course specialist 'stream' in the BFA(Hons), BMA(Hons) and/or BDes(Hons) programs completed over Years 2 and 3.

This course relates to companion courses in the Jewellery studio stream particularly SDES2409 by providing an introduction to contemporary jewellery and object design in association with other  Year 2 courses in preparation for more advanced studies in Year 3.
contentlets.title: Jewellery Narratives, Concepts and Materials

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES2409 - Jewellery Production: Synergies between Hand and Machine","description":"

In this mid-level jewellery course, students investigate ideas between the hand and the machine. These parameters of jewellery production will engage students with concerns relating to contemporary jewellery design practice and acquire technical knowledge and skills with material and conceptual issues. Designs will be realised as finished objects through both hand fabrication and prototyping of jewellery works. Projects will address the conceptual, material and technical understandings of Jewellery and Object Design employing analysis, research, problem-solving and design development to produce design solutions. In this course, particular attention is paid to the dialogue between new technologies and traditional craft skills in the design and production of Jewellery and Objects.


This course will focus students on a thorough examination of three dimensional jewellery and object design using the body as the format or site for design solutions. This course extends experimentation and the development of an understanding of techniques from both traditional hand fabrication and small- scale industrial processes including computer modelling, prototyping and casting. Research and experimentation will be undertaken with a variety of metal and non-metal materials and techniques. Studio activity will combine the development of one-off designs and the production of multiples as wearable jewellery objects.


Students will study and engage with traditional and new technological approaches over the entire semester with three assessment tasks. Students will work between the Jewellery Studio, Makers Space and liaise with industry at different stages of the project in order to realise their proposal.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"0ade70bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961939","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"The Hand Built Brooch/Pin","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

This studio-based Task develops one or a series of hand-built soldered wearable works; Brooch/Pin Forms and an Artist Card which explores the notion of micro (small) mega (great). ‘Mikromegas’, which translates roughly to ‘small works, large ideas’. The outcomes will be material experiments and wearable brooch/pin. In addition to studio attendance and participation your weekly access to and use of the Moodle Jewel Blog to record your work is compulsory and assessable. Your blog should include research, artist’s concept statement, detailing processes, ideas and influences.

Submission details:

1. One or a Series of Hand-Built Soldered Brooch/Pin

2. Artist Card no larger than A5 format

3. Jewel Blog showing:

• Research • Artist’s concept statement (200-word maximum) • Processes • Ideas & Influences

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"46de70bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96192d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"cede70bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"75de70bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96191f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Casting About","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

Consider the notion of Migration as a theme to develop into a concept and translate the ideas into finished Jewellery or Object solutions that involve casting.

This project will conclude with a finished work or series of works that employ casting as a technique.

You are required to research and respond your ideas into a Design Portfolio containing no more than 800 words. The design portfolio should consider the presentation layout and your graphic communication skills. The format should not be larger than 30 x 30 cm. The design porfolio should detail:

1. Concept Statement

2. Background/Content

3. Precedence Studies

4. Presentation Rendering of the Work/s (minimum of one design)

5. Specifications of Materials

6. Referencing using APA style

The design/s can be completely made from casting processes or include cast elements that are incorporated into hand-built forms. To prepare for the casting process a number of pathways or a combination of pathways may be utilised. This will be discussed in studio lectures.

You are required to create and complete the work/s. The finished work/s should reflect the research undertaken in your design portfolio. It should be a wearable/s or object/s employing casting within its design. The work is to be resolved and finished. It should be hand-made, predominantly in metal. In some instances, you will be required to liaise with industry such as casting foundry, 3D printers and other industries as part of your problem solving in the design and making processes.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"0ede70bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961935","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"46de70bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96192d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"82de70bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961930","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"cede70bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bdde70bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961923","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SDES2409.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

This specialist course covers foundation studio knowledge, skills and professional methodologies for object design. In particular, you will learn to engage in a design practice, which integrates technical knowledge and skills with material, form and contextual issues in contemporary object design. You will explore the relationship between an object's meaning (both social/cultural) and its material properties, structural qualities, construction methods, finishes, fittings and connections. Projects will address the conceptual, material and sculptural understandings of 3D object design.


You will develop an understanding of scale models, drawing conventions and their presentation, in particular working to scale, using notations, dimensions and the use of drawings for 3D computer modelling, digital visualisation, prototyping and presentation. Through a series of lectures and demonstrations you will be informed of the different skills, knowledge and abilities a designer requires in order to create a three dimensional object.


You will work on one project throughout the course and have three sequential assessment tasks covering; research and concepts, design development and final design synthesis and presentation. You will work between the design studio, object design fabrication space and computer lab at different stages in order to realise the project.


SDES2410 Object Design Dialogues is an introductory 2000 level studio course. It is one of a suite of two interrelated core courses in Year 2 that contribute to a four-course specialist object 'stream' in the BDes(Hons) programs completed over Years 2 and 3.
