contentlets.description:
This specialist course covers foundation studio knowledge, skills and professional methodologies for object design. In particular, you will learn to engage in a design practice, which integrates technical knowledge and skills with material, form and contextual issues in contemporary object design. You will explore the relationship between an object's meaning (both social/cultural) and its material properties, structural qualities, construction methods, finishes, fittings and connections. Projects will address the conceptual, material and sculptural understandings of 3D object design.

You will develop an understanding of scale models, drawing conventions and their presentation, in particular working to scale, using notations, dimensions and the use of drawings for 3D computer modelling, digital visualisation, prototyping and presentation. Through a series of lectures and demonstrations you will be informed of the different skills, knowledge and abilities a designer requires in order to create a three dimensional object.

You will work on one project throughout the course and have three sequential assessment tasks covering; research and concepts, design development and final design synthesis and presentation. You will work between the design studio, object design fabrication space and computer lab at different stages in order to realise the project.

SDES2410 Object Design Dialogues is an introductory 2000 level studio course. It is one of a suite of two interrelated core courses in Year 2 that contribute to a four-course specialist object 'stream' in the BDes(Hons) programs completed over Years 2 and 3.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES2411 - Object Typologies: Reuse, Recycle","description":"


In this specialist course, design solutions are developed from briefs that address the social value of furniture and object design including the reuse and recycling of materials forms and ideas. You will develop skills in analysing and articulating primary and secondary research including theories of slow-design, co-design and meta-design in both 2D & 3D formats. You will develop an understanding of sustainable approaches to your design process and apply scenario building and collaborative skills to resolve your design outcome.


You will undertake three assessment tasks; a life cycle analysis report, investigative research and scenario building, and the design and fabrication of a full-scale prototype. You will use basic computer skills to represent ideas, working drawings and communicate project presentation.

You will be presented with a series of lectures and demonstrations of the different skills, knowledge and abilities a designer requires in order to undertake the creation of a three dimensional object. In studio tutorials students will extend the range of analytical skills in relationship to form, materials, and production processes relevant to furniture and object design by participating in different problem solving scenarios.


SDES2411 Object Typologies: Reuse, Recycle is an introductory 2000 level studio course. It is one of a suite of two interrelated core courses in Year 2 that contribute to a four-course specialist object 'stream' in the BDes(Hons) programs completed over Years 2 and 3.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"0cdefc7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619dd","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Deconstruct – Reuse/Recycle","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Designing a chair can be a very complex task. Often the first question you ask yourself is “What is a Chair?”  In groups of 2 or 3, select a chair and review the chair’s function, construction and materials. You are asked to examine the interior and exterior of the chair and develop an understanding of construction methodologies and principles in manufacture. Deconstruct the chair and compile a report using sketches and photographs to articulate your process during class time.

In your groups conduct a life cycle analysis on the materials found in the chair. Include a review of the context of the chair in regards to use, ergonomics, and cultural relevance or period from which it comes. This report requires you to utilise computer skills in both layout of information and possibly 3d modeling of the chair.

Include a review of the existing chairs in regards to their history and previous use.

Demonstrate your understanding of the chair’s construction in sketch details including materials, processes and analysis of production techniques.

Include a life cycle analysis of the chair’s components.

Please upload your reports in PDF format to the server and prepare a class presentation summarizing the content of your report.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b7cefc7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619d4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"23cefc7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619bf","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seating Scenarios","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Does design have a value beyond comfort, fashion and style? You are asked to explore the different ways in which we use furniture by conducting primary research into different scenarios of seating. What are, the social, political or ideological values inherent in seating?

This task asks you to design a seating solution that challenges ideas about sitting in public or private spaces.

The ideas your seating scenario could challenge may concern ergonomics (the physicality of sitting), social concepts for sitting (how people communicate and interact), or wellbeing, mobility, or other issue approved in discussion with your tutor. 

The seating design must be designed to bear the minimum weight of 150kg. 

The seating design must address sustainability or environmental/ecological issues in some way. Designers should consider sustainability issues, such as low impact materials, durabilities, lifespan, maintenance and/or the end of life (separation for recycling, or alternative uses for components). Social or political response to problems of the environment are also possible.

Consider:

•        the integration of features that contribute to the functionality of the chair. (For example, in a chair design for campus use by students, an integrated storage space that could accommodate a typical backpack. For a chair designed for private interior use, features that facilitate domestic processes or rituals.)

•        the mobility of the chair in regard to your seating scenario. Is it easy to move and/or reconfigure? Is it integrated with something that moves itself, or is immovable?

•        durability. Is the chair made of materials that will withstand regular use. Are these materials designed or intended to age or resist wear? Can they be replaced or repaired? 

Submission details:

•        A typed, A4 explanation of what you have tried to express in your design and the designs attributes.

•        2 x A3 presentation boards illustrating the seating in use, key features of the design and a measured drawings or general assembly drawing.

•        A 1:5 scale presentation model of the final design in appropriate materials.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7bcefc7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619d1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c0defc7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619d7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6bcefc7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"New Typologies","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

From your concept model of your seating scenario develop the design into a working prototype.

Your design should clearly reflect your understanding of this scenario.

Your working prototype should take into consideration your end user needs, service provider requirements and consider the social cultural context.

You are expected to draw upon your existing model making skills and can utilise manufacturing processes if appropriate. Workshop advice and assistance will be given to you throughout the session in producing your final outcome.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES2412 - Spatial Design: Experimental Domestic Spaces","description":"

This course introduces the theory and practice of domestic space design. Through an exploration of the concept of home in lectures intended to engage, inform and inspire, you will examine a wide range of domestic typologies from the practical (e.g. capsule hotels, emergency housing, studio flats) to the experimental (e.g. pop-up installations, aviaries, fairground fun houses). In a studio-based environment, you will critically analyse precedent designs and respond creatively to client briefs for the design of domestic spaces by applying key principles of mind-body-environment relations to your concept and design development. Analysing domestic spaces as sets of points, planes and patterns, you will learn to explore, experiment with, and communicate your proposals through models built by hand and with digital software. In developing these skills you will also become familiar with some of the professional opportunities open to spatial designers, including building design, installation design, model-making, and architectural visualisation.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"aecebc7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619fa","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 3: High Density Living","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

In teams of two, your task is to design and build a modular system appropriate for constructing high-density dwellings in flexible formations. You will model the form at two scales in order to illustrate its combinatory relations and the volumes it can produce.

Verbal peer and tutor feedback during development phase in studio; written self- and peer assessment on submission; written tutor feedback according to a criterion matrix correlated to the learning outcomes set out above and communicated electronically within two weeks of submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"22cebc7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619cf","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"96cebc7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"a2cebc7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619f7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e2cebc7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619cc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1acebc7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 1: Precedent Studies","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will examine, document and critique spatial precedents of 'home'. Documentation will involve modelling and drawing the precedents.

Verbal peer and tutor feedback during development phase in studio; written self- and peer assessment on submission; written tutor feedback according to a criterion matrix correlated to the learning outcomes set out above and communicated electronically within two weeks of submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"96cebc7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"86cebc7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619aa","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 2: Single Volume Spaces","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

With housing affordability and workspace space in Sydney at an all-time low, the State government is testing out a possible solution. Each student will receive a standard 20-foot shipping container (interior dimensions = 5485mm (l) x 2250mm (w) x 2260 (h)). The task is to design a complete home office/studio as an independent living unit equipped with kitchen, bathroom, and sleeping facilities.

Verbal peer and tutor feedback during development phase in studio; written self- and peer assessment on submission; written tutor feedback according to a criterion matrix correlated to the learning outcomes set out above and communicated electronically within two weeks of submission.

contentlets.keywords: design studies,spatial design,interior design,landscape design,experiential design,building design,model-making,design drawing,domestic interior,2d,3d,4d design,vectorworks,photoshop
contentlets.description: This course introduces the theory and practice of domestic space design. Through an exploration of the concept of home in lectures intended to engage, inform and inspire, you will examine a wide range of domestic typologies from the practical (e.g. capsule hotels, emergency housing, studio flats) to the experimental (e.g. pop-up installations, aviaries, fairground fun houses). In a studio-based environment, you will critically analyse precedent designs and respond creatively to client briefs for the design of domestic spaces by applying key principles of mind-body-environment relations to your concept and design development. Analysing domestic spaces as sets of points, planes and patterns, you will learn to explore, experiment with, and communicate your proposals through models built by hand and with digital software. In developing these skills you will also become familiar with some of the professional opportunities open to spatial designers, including building design, installation design, model-making, and architectural visualisation.
contentlets.title: Spatial Design: Experimental Domestic Spaces

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES2413 - Spatial Design: Experimental Public Spaces","description":"

This course introduces the foundational principles of public space design, exploring mind-body-environment relations as a system of networks, nodes, and pathways. In lectures intended to engage, inform and inspire, you will interrogate the concepts of movement, rest and meeting through diverse precedents, ranging from courtyard gardens and pocket parks to retail and exhibition spaces, city squares, and even entire cities. In studio-based assignments you will respond to client briefs for innovative public space design, applying principles to practice. Through this process, you will learn to explore and communicate your proposals through drawings, including plans, sections and elevations, executed by hand and with digital software. In developing these skills you will also become familiar with professional opportunities open to spatial designers in the areas of urban design, landscape design, and exhibition design.







","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c5cebc7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96191e","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Darlo Masterplan","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Groupwork: in groups of three.

Scenario: In light of the recent designation by the NSW State Government of Oxford Street & Surrounds (Darlinghurst) as Sydney’s Pilot ‘Arts, Culture & Innovation Precinct’, the City of Sydney has invited you to develop a masterplan that balances opportunities and responsibilities for recreational, residential and commercial activities in the area. 

This plan will treat the day-time, night-time and transition economies as integrated rhythms of a 24 hour cycle.
You may choose to relocate the Supreme Court, public transport & traffic, and pedestrianise any council-controlled roads/laneways, but you must account for how you will maintain or enhance the current level of access and service provision. 

Your plan must include 100 x 80m2 apartments, one or more significants works of Public Art and maintain (or increase) the current level of retail space.

NB: City of Sydney owns most of the north side of Oxford Street (b/n Riley St & Taylor Sq) and the potential for a world-best-practice re-development of these sites should not be ignored. Any new development must incorporate high levels of insulation & soundproofing and supply minimum percentages of affordable creative space and housing. 

Submission requirements: Poster or series of drawings (electronic), photographs of models, and journal (electronic) and 2 minute formative verbal presentation. Drawings and models to include concepts, masterplans, sketches, site plans, plans, sections, elevations, perspectives, diagrams and mages.  

A digital version of all the posters/drawings should be combined into 1 PDF document (no larger than 40MB). This PDF,  as well as a separate PDF curated copy of your journal (no larger than 20 MB), must be uploaded to Moodle by 9am on the day of submission. In addition to your two minute verbal presentation, you will be required to participate in peer feedback and class discussions regarding the submissions.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8dcebc7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961917","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c1ce7c7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619fc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c9cebc7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96191a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3cce7c7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619f2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Macquarie Place Site Analysis","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

This project introduces you to the importance of undertaking a site analysis when designing public spaces, and will use Macquarie Place (Bridge Street, Sydney) as a case study. 

Applying the site analysis methods introduced to you in class, conduct a site visit outside of studio time and record, analyse and evaluate key information. This could include physical characteristics, environmental factors, the relationship between the site and its surroundings, its current and previous functions, any natural and built structures and systems, historical background, key stakeholders, user perceptions, and so on. You are also required to identify any strengths, weaknesses and opportunities that you believe the site presents, and outline a vision for how Macquarie Place could be better utilised. 

Your final site analysis, evaluation and proposed vision should be presented in an A1 poster format and must include a combination of sketches, plans, sections, perspectives, images and text (300 words maximum) to communicate your findings. Your journal must also be presented at the time of pin up.

Posters are to be printed and pinned up at the start of studio class, along with your journal. A digital copy of the poster only (no larger than 40MB) must be uploaded to Moodle by 9am on the day of submission. No formal verbal presentation is required, but you will be required to participate in peer feedback and class discussions regarding the submissions.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c1ce7c7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619fc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b8ce7c7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619e9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"7-11 Park","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"45","description":"

Scenario: After acquiring the 7-11 petrol station on Oxford/Napier Street the University of New South Wales wants to develop the site as an “experimental public space” to provide the Faculty of Art and Design with a strong presence on Oxford Street. The University is holding a design competition to find the best proposal. 

The competition brief states that "The design should provide public open space clearly branded as part of UNSW and suitable for the display of permanent and temporary art works by UNSW Art + Design students and staff.  It must feature universal access and include seating for a minimum of fifteen people. All materials, finishes, street furniture, and signage must be specified.”

Submit a poster (or series of posters or drawings that can be any size of your choosing) and model (to a suitable scale) which includes precedent studies, your conceptual approach and proposed design illustrated with appropriate plans, sections, elevations, perspectives, images, sketches and diagrams. Your journal must be presented at the time of pin up. You will be required to complete a one minute verbal presentation.

Posters are to be printed and pinned up at the start of studio class. A digital copy of the poster(s) (no larger than 40MB) as well as a PDF curated copy of your journal (no larger than 20 MB) must be uploaded to Moodle by 9am on the day of submission.  In addition to your one minute verbal presentation, you will be required to participate in peer feedback and class discussions regarding the submissions.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES2414 - Sustainable Design: Theories and Practice","description":"

Sustainable Design examines the emergence of key concepts in sustainability theory and their impact on design practice since the Industrial Revolution. With a focus on the agency of design professions in accelerating social and material development, students think critically, analyse and discuss key questions connecting design thinking, design practice and implications for quality of life in the short and longer term. This course underlines the significance of sustainability within and beyond the design professions, of particular relevance to the fields of creative practice, environmental studies, manufacturing, business, law and politics.


Sustainable Design: Theories and Practice will provide students with a framework for understanding key concepts in sustainable design, assisting you to locate, identify and creatively engage with important underpinning themes and contemporary interpretations that have influenced and continue to shape contemporary design practice. A scholarly approach explores a wide range of sources related to interdisciplinary design issues and pragmatic considerations including systemic relationships between natural and anthropological systems, the dynamics of social, economic and environmental contexts for design, and attitudes towards responsibility in contemporary practice. 


Faculty of Art & Design students can select this stand-alone course from an approved list to satisfy core requirements in the BFA(Hons), BMA(Hons) or BDes(Hons) programs. Where places are available, other students may also take this course as either a free elective or general education course.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"3fbe7c7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961927","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 2: Perspectives on Sustainable Design: Life Cycle Analysis","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

Students form teams of 2 to carry out a Life Cycle Analysis of a commonly available designed object, and will present your analysis as a digital poster for classroom display. 

To do this:

  • Select an artifact.
  • Provide a brief explanation of the artifact and its purpose, including an image;
  • Describe in as much detail as possible the life cycle of the artifact from design through ?production, distribution, use and disposal.
  • Note the environmental impacts of this life cycle.
  • Propose alternatives to reduce the impact.
  • Present your findings as a self-explanatory diagram for pin-up
  • Give a 5 minute group presentation in class to accompany your poster, with 5 minutes of questions and discussion with your class.
  • Reference sources of information you have used for this project.

You will receive peer feedback from your colleagues, written and verbal feedback from your tutor

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"23be7c7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961924","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e3be7c7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961921","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1bbe3c7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619f7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 3: Design and Social Behaviour - Major essay and review","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

In teams of 2, students identify a sustainable design practice and develop a critically reflective case study around it. 

The prevailing social context for design can be described as a state of 'wicked problems'  that must be negotiated to facilitate sustainable outcomes. In this task students will apply simple research methods to make observations, source information and evaluate a range of social, technical and economic conditions to better understand their impact on environmental sustainability. Students write a 2,500 word essay based on their investigation which critically evaluates the vectors contributing to an unsustainable condition and propose a strategic design solution that will likely result in more sustainable practices. A list of prospective issues will be provided as a platform from which you can source your own scenario. Both the design decisions developed in your essay and the position taken in your review should reference theories and practices studied in the course.

Present it in A4 format 11 pt font size, using the Footnote / Bibliography referencing system, and including images of the designs/design practices. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"23be7c7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961924","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a7be7c7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96191e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e3be7c7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961921","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"53be3c7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619fc","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 1: The Ethical Dimension of Everyday Things","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Students are to select one specific designed artefact (an object, space, graphic, etc.) and engage in an analysis of ethical issues in as much detail as possible. 

Students present their analysis as a 1250-word report. It must be fully referenced using the Footnote / Referencing system. Present it in A4 format 11pt font size and include images of the designed artefact.

Feedback will be provided verbally in tutorial and in written format by your tutor.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES2415 - Experimental Design","description":"

This subject introduces foundation knowledge of the historical background and context of contemporary experimental design. The course engages with a range of histories, themes and practices of experimental design. It will cover experimental design from the late 19th century to the 1980s for historical context but focus on the period since the 1990s. Students explore dominant paradigms of design including functionalism, innovation, avant-gardism and social reform, and engage with theoretical design discourse concerned with consumerism, globalization and sustainability. The subject will demonstrate the interdisciplinary facets of experimental design in relation to design theory, visual art and design practices.


Assessment in this course includes tutorial presentations, written essays and contributions to class discussion.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"12be3c7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961930","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 1: Annotated Bibliography","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Select one of the lecture topics that are addressed by an experimental design or designer/s in contemporary  graphic, furniture and fashion design and prepare an annotated bibliography of at least six key references for the design, designer or topic. The references should be a mix of popular and scholary citations and sourced from your database searches rather than the course outline.

Feedback will be provided in Review with written comments

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4ebe3c7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961923","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7dbe3c7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961904","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 3: Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

1,500-word essay with supporting visual documentation and accurate referencing. Describe and analyze an experimental design or designer’s work in graphic, furniture, or fashion design, drawing on a theoretical framework discussed during the semester. The essay must demonstrate critical engagement with design discourse on a contemporary issue, such as globalization, sustainability and consumerism.

Feedback will be provided in Review with written comments

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"16be3c7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96192c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d6be3c7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961929","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"86be3c7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96191a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 2: Audiovisual Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will produce a 10-minute audiovisual presentation of a selected design or designer within the thematic of Assessment Task 1.  Students will also produce a 1,000-word summary supplemented with visual supports is due in week 7.

Feedback will be provided in Review with written comments

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES2416 - Dreams of Home: Four Centuries of Australian Domestic Design","description":"

This course explores the historical context of Australian domestic design from the gunyah and wattle-and-daub hut to the contemporary highrise apartment, via the Victorian terrace and the suburban subdivision, providing you the opportunity to contextualise your own practices within a history of domestic place-making informed by the current challenge to develop sustainable ways of living. Investigating how design has both reflected and constructed notions of home , literally and metaphorically, we will encounter many different lived experiences, including those of indigenous peoples, women, children and migrants. Dreams of Home explores these experiences through the lenses of urban, architectural and interior design history, analysing domestic artefacts such as ceramics, textiles, furniture and lighting, examining domestic spaces such as the parlour, patio, garden and courtyard, and considering domestic activities from the garage sale to the backyard barbie and the TV dinner. In the classroom you will read and discuss key texts, and in the field you will carry out site and artefact analysis. Crucially, you will encounter domestic experience through the voices of those who have lived them: in addition to reading historical accounts, you will be introduced to the practice of oral history, making recordings and analysing the accounts of the lived experience of the Australian home.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"78bef87fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96194e","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"My History, My Space","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

At the beginning of term you will be assigned one of the required texts (either a reading or video). In the week that you are scheduled to present (in weeks 3-10) you will give a 20-minute presentation. In the first five minutes, summarise the key points of the text.  In the final 15 minutes of the presentation, introduce the class to your own relationship to the topic, and critically analyse the role that design has played in that relationship, illustrating your talk with images, artefacts, and accounts of personal experience.

The session will end with a class/group discussion in which other students will respond to your talk relating it to their own experience.

Submission details

In-class presentations will be due weekly from week 3. (A schedule will be established in week 1). Submission will be marked inside and outside class, but only criterion 2, "capacity to engage class through image and speech" will be assessed during the in-class presentations. Formative feedback will be given in class following the presentation. This feedback should be incorporated into a revised written report which will be submitted via Moodle in Week 11.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"30bef87fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961948","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f0bef87fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961945","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2cbef87fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96192a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"The Meaning of Home","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"45","description":"

You are required to research the lived experience of domestic design by interviewing one of your classmates. Your objective is to determine how their experience of domestic design reflects broader contextual influences of the kind we explore in class and in readings. With the subject’s consent, you will conduct a site visit, documenting designs at all scales, and also conduct an interview to understand how the subject’s current experience of home is both reflected in and constructed by elements of design. (If you choose not to invite classmates into your home, please inform your tutor. Alternative arrangements can be made.)

You will transcribe and edit the interview recording, and include the transcription as an appendix to your report. Present your findings as annotated plans, photographs, with key points summarised in an accompanying 1500-word (max) report.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7cbef87fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96194a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f0bef87fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961945","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2cbef87fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96193b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mapping the Territory","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

With reference to elements of ‘domestic design’ at all scales, provide a portrait of the socio-cultural character of two streets.

To do this, select two contrasting, primarily residential streets in the Sydney area. For each street, survey the built environment, documenting its historical development, housing types, landscaping, street conditions, etc. The report should provide a comprehensive description of each street, so choose either a relatively short street or a section of a longer street that is representative of the whole or a significant part. 

Based on your survey, discuss the social, economic and other factors that have produced and are reflected in design elements of each street. Present your findings as an illustrated report, featuring annotated plans, photographs and diagrams, with key findings contained in an executive summary of 1000 words. The report should contain evidence of a comprehensive site investigation and critical interpretation of the data informed by relevant design theories, as presented in lectures and readings.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"SDES2463","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES2463 - Graphics Media: Typography and Publication Design","description":"

This course involves cultural, historical, and practical exploration of typographic and publication design. The relationship between typography as an expressive medium and its technological development is explored through a series of studio workshops. Publications such as books and magazines in print and screen media are developed to gain an advanced understanding of dynamic typography, print and screen architecture, and information layout for publication.


Assessment in this course includes studio research tasks and projects that engage with image generation and typography, publication design for online delivery and publication style-guides.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"528a22e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619c9","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Letterpress Postcards","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

This project invites students to engage in conceptual development and studio research to generate a range of approaches to contemporary letterpress design. Exploration of visual hierachy and the relationship between typography, grid and image will culminate in the synthesis and production of a series of type-based letterpress postcard designs, addressing a current public issue. Students are asked to engage in detailed design iteration and resolution, and evidence experimentation, scholarly enquiry and critical reflection through a comprehensive and curated visual journal.

\n","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"528a22e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619b6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c68a22e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619b0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"028a22e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a961996","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online Publication Design","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

Assessment 2 requires students to collaborate in design teams towards the development and resolution of a downloadable online publication. Each student will undertake a role within the team according to individual design strengths and interests to develop, design and publish the publication. Students work individually and collaboratively to produce and design original content on their chosen focus topic, which should be within or relating to typography. Deliverables include cover design, contents page, advertisements, articles and an accompanying style guide. 

\n","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"168a22e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619b3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"528a22e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619b6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"9e8a22e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619b8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c68a22e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619b0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4a8a22e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a96199a","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SDES2463.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES2464 - Cultural Textiles: Field Trips","description":"

Cultural Textiles: Field Trip is a short-term overseas study course to study textiles in a specific Asian country. The course focuses on artisan produced textiles, giving students the opportunity to understand the cultural, social and environmental issues impacting on production, with the potential of future engagement via major projects, research studies or to engage locally in design projects. The countries where Cultural Textiles: Field Trip course may be conducted are India, Indonesia, Thailand, Laos and Japan. 


The program allows students to benefit from lectures by regional experts; research textiles in museums; see demonstrations of textiles being made; participate in workshops conducted in artisan or community centres; meet designers and artisans; and learn about the issues impacting on this field of contemporary design.


The Cultural Textiles course will focus the how, where, what and the nature of production by artisan, family, village and community groups. Of particular interest is how textile traditions are maintained by these groups, how organizations work to maintain these traditions and how textiles traditions impact on contemporary designs. The Cultural Textiles course allows students to study, research and experience specific textile techniques giving them insights into how to design for, collaborate with, commission or engage with these artisan groups in the future. The various textiles techniques covered by the course depends on the location but will include a selection from block or ajarkh printing; specific embroidery techniques; resist patterning techniques eg bandani, shibori or ikat; or interlacing techniques such as weaving, basketry, ply splitting or twinning. 


Introductory seminar(s) are held at the Faculty of Art & Design prior to departure. Assessment tasks comprise a detailed travel journal; a range of textile design croquis (ideas) and a major research essay. Submission of projects will be 3 to 4 weeks after the end of the field trip component of the course. 


Note: This course is suited to UG students in their 3rd or 4th year of their course; students are responsible for their own travel arrangements and associated costs during the field trip eg accommodation, workshop fees, internal travel; an additional up-front fee is required by the Faculty of Art & Design to cover the specific cost of delivering the field trip component of the course overseas. Estimates of these costs will be available once the specific field trip location has been announced. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"051e1dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96194b","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Cultural Textiles Documentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

This task is to document each day of the fieldwork course and your experience of being overseas through a journal, or in specifically approved cases, a video. 

Work in your journal in the way that suits you - this can include sketches, drawing, diagrams, images, writings, found objects, photos, brochures etc.

Your journal or video should document your field trip experience, places visited, demonstrations, presentation on artisan textiles, workshops given as part of the course and the issues impacting on the handloom sector. It should include observations of culture, life, environment, artisan objects, textiles, patterns, structures and information gathered from presentations, workshops, visits etc. It should also include design or art ideas to represent your experiences.Your journal or video should provide comprehensive documentation of your experience during the Cultural Textiles course and be a substantial record of Cultural Textiles fieldwork course.

Your journal is to include four short reports on selected social enterprise organisations or designers or artisan communities visited during the fieldwork component of the course. You will need to include these four reports in your journal; each report should be at least 200 words and include appropriate referencing and full acknowledgement of all quotes, images and text. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"091e1dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961947","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c91e1dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961944","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b81e1dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961924","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"A range of textile art or design ideas / croquis","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

Develop a range of art or design ideas for contemporary textiles that could be made by a selected artisan or community group visited during the Cultural Textiles 2020 fieldwork course. 

Art ideas should illustrate ideas for an exhibition or project; this could be an exhibition of your work but include artwork made by the artisan group; or it could be a collaborative project with the artisan group with artwork jointly made by the artisan group and you. 

A design range comprises designs for textiles. As croquis, they do not need to show a repeat; these should show colours appropriate for your design with infomarion on how they will be made eg if block printed in natural designs then use appropriate colours. These can be textile or on paper (collaged, printed or painted).

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"SDES3166","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES3166 - Jewellery Design for Fashion","description":"

Students will develop an understanding of contemporary jewellery practice and explore the concepts of jewellery as expressed in a fashion context. This practical class will involve the design of both wearable and non-wearable body related objects. Students will be encouraged through a range experimentation in materials and processes to focus their making on the production of jewellery in the studio environment.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"d221c137db391c50eb6b147a3a961922","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Translation","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Take as a starting point the work completed for Assessment Task 1, based on your selected designer, and through a series of design manipulations, develop and produce a range of work suitable for small-scale production, which effectively moves your focus from the runway to the high street.

Your high street collection should comprise at least three pieces of finished jewellery. You may choose to make a suite of related work (ie: earrings, neckpiece, bracelet) or focus on a capsule collection of one style of jewellery (ie: earrings)

Your design should allow for materials to be soldered, riveted, or linked/wrapped together in some way by using cold joining techniques. You must include a metal component on each piece and incorporate at least two dissimilar materials. Your work is to be wearable and finished to a high standard. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5a21c137db391c50eb6b147a3a961909","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"9a21c137db391c50eb6b147a3a96191b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"d621c137db391c50eb6b147a3a96191e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0a218137db391c50eb6b147a3a9619fa","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Design Collaboration","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

This section of the subject is about you becoming aware of the work of others in the field of jewellery who may have some bearing or similarity to the work you have commenced in this subject. You are required to research the ‘context’ within which your selected designers work and produce. It requires you to choose 2 designers from different countries.

- Sit outside your usual comfort zone - do not automatically go to your favourite local designers.
- The 2 designers you choose must employ traditional or contemporary making methods of jewellery and not be from the long list who primarily construct from bought and found components, ie. beads closures, everyday charms, etc. (If you are not sure if the chosen designers are suitable check with your lecturer before starting your essay).

Note any similarities or differences in design, function, form, symbolism, and materials used by each designer. Analyse their work, interpreting any cultural, historical and contemporary references. In your own words explain what makes the work in each of the examples relevant to you.

You are required to research and write a short paper of 800 words analyzing the work of each designer. Your essay should include coloured images of at least one (1) typical example of their past work and one (1) of their recent work – these works should be discussed in your writing.

Provide a title for your essay, references and a bibliography.
* do not rely on the Internet for this area of the subject research.

Referencing Requirements for Assessments

This course follows the Footnote / Bibliography referencing system. Guidelines on how to reference according to this system can be found at: https://student.unsw.edu.au/footnote-bibliography-or-oxford- referencing-system and at: https://student.unsw.edu.au/citing-different-sources-0 and
at: https://student.unsw.edu.au/bibliography-or-list-references . You should follow ONLY these guidelines in your assessment tasks.

Accurate and correct referencing is an important academic prerequisite 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1e21c137db391c50eb6b147a3a961906","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ce21c137db391c50eb6b147a3a961903","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ce218137db391c50eb6b147a3a9619f5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research and Studio Task: A Wearable Work for a Selected Fashion Designer + Magazine Cover Illustrating the Work","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

You are to research and analyse the work of a known fashion designer* or fashion house, and produce a wearable work (finished conceptual jewellery piece) that complements the designer’s style and is suitable for the runway. This can be for a Womenswear or Menswear collection; you need to choose a specific collection and allow that collection to influence your work. The site for the work will be the human body; you are required to design and make a finished work.

(* Dior is not designed by Christian Dior).
Your finished work is to be supported by a fashion magazine cover, using an image of the Runway piece.

The project requires you to research and experiment with appropriate materials, informed by your research which will be presented on an A3 Concept board. Design considerations will include: The Season, Theme, Fabrications and colours, prints etc.

When thinking through this brief, you need to consider the dynamic of the piece in its context, on the Runway at a Ready to Wear Fashion week show in a major city such as Paris, Milan, London, New York.

Part A: Concept Board – This is to be an A3 board, which provides a visual narrative of your chosen designer’s work. You are to select key images that exemplify the work and collection of your chosen designer, being careful to pay attention to design details, as well as to silhouettes and colour choices. You must include the elements that you see are important to the designer’s work as well as sketches of your design. Make sure your presentation is coherent, succinct and professional and effectively conveys this information, as well as your own unique conceptual direction. A draft of your concept board is to be presented for feedback in Week 2.

Part B: The Magazine Cover - a styled image of your finished work on the body. Your design must reflect both the work that you develop and make and the chosen designer’s style, the cover layout and quality of the image are of paramount importance. You must include text, including the magazine masthead, in your cover layout. The magazine cover is to be presented as a high-quality colour print, securely and neatly mounted on cardboard or foam-core.

Part C: Completed Conceptual Jewellery Piece – a conceptual Jewellery piece, worn on the body that reflects the chosen designers style, collection and season. This work is to be large in scale, designed to feature in a runway show of your selected fashion designer. This piece is to feature on your Magazine Cover. Your work is to be supported by material experimentation, sampling and model-making – this is to be presented at assessment and documented on the Moodle Jewel Blog. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"5e21c137db391c50eb6b147a3a961918","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ce21c137db391c50eb6b147a3a961903","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"fd218137db391c50eb6b147a3a9619e4","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SDES3166.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.keywords: design studies,sdes3166
contentlets.description: Students will develop an understanding of contemporary jewellery practice and explore the concepts of jewellery as expressed in a fashion context. This practical class will involve the design of both wearable and non-wearable body related objects. Students will be encouraged through a range experimentation in materials and processes to focus their making on the production of jewellery in the studio environment.
contentlets.title: Jewellery Design for Fashion

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES3172 - Digital Design: Introduction to Interactive Design","description":"

This interactive media elective will prepare you for the digital design industry and introduce you to key concepts, skills, technologies and ways of thinking used by innovative interactive design practices. You will explore various approaches and software, research content, create and apply interactive strategies and use techniques to development of dynamic responsive content for newly emerging open-source standards. The content may include: critical analysis of selected designs, physical implementations, animations and interactive coding techniques.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"ef2fbcbfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619de","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 1: Initial research findings and presentation of Case Study","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will research and identify how interactive data visualisations are currently used to communicate relevant information. Students will document these investigations with any appropriate form of media (social media, image, video and upload this documentation to a blog that will be presented in class.

Assignment 2 will develop a plan of action and a precise approach based on this task, and Assignment 3 will implement student research and findings.  

Students will recieve verbal and/or written feedback

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"a72fbcbfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619d8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5b2fbcbfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 3: Interactive visualisation Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will create an interactive visualisation, based upon the proposals developed in Assessment 2 (and subsequent discussions) that utilises Processing or another programming environments as the primary means to present interactive content.

Students will receive verbal and/or written feedback.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6b2fbcbfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619d5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e32fbcbfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619db","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"932fbcbfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619bb","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 2: Project Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Students are to develop a visualisation of an identified a metric, physical or and/social characteristic(s) of a particular circumstance or situation. In this assignment, student groups will propose ways in which they will develop and identify the mechanisms to implement this concept. 

The assignment will be presented in class as a 10-minute (PowerPoint or similar) and should present a conceptual rational for the work and a production treatment i.e. feasibility: propose design requirements use timelines, map or other mechanisms to present foreseeable challengers. The final document should provide the structural basis for the completion of Assignment 3.

Students will receive verbal and/or written feedback.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"SDES3174","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES3174 - Digital Design - Introduction to Web Design","description":"

This course will prepare you for the digital design industry by focusing on the processes involved in the creation, design and development of web content. It provides an introduction to the basic underlying technologies and methodologies of client-side web design and development. It covers basic web page composition using HTML, CSS and JavaScript as the underlying mechanism for realising creative, online content.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"51bf06ebdbf59850eb6b147a3a961904","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Translation from blueprint to site","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

For assessment 3, create the website outlined in your blueprint using HTML 5, CSS 3 and JavaScript.

Note: You must evidence changes can be made to the structure / content / design outlined in your original blueprint based upon during verbal feedback given to you in the compulsory consultations and this changed document re-named revised version, will be uploaded with your final build as evidence of iterative design development.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"19bfc2ebdbf59850eb6b147a3a9619fd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"55bf06ebdbf59850eb6b147a3a961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d9bfc2ebdbf59850eb6b147a3a9619fa","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"05bfc2ebdbf59850eb6b147a3a9619f1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Design, Semantic HTML & CSS","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"35","description":"

A lot of traditional ideas and terms from print publishing have made their way into web terminology, header, below-the-fold, page, stylesheet and so on. Students must take a print magazine and design a website homepage for the magazine. Once you have completed the design, you will build the webpage as a semantic HTML  document using HTML 5 & CSS 3.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"19bfc2ebdbf59850eb6b147a3a9619fd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d9bfc2ebdbf59850eb6b147a3a9619fa","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"81bfc2ebdbf59850eb6b147a3a9619e8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Website blueprint","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

You will be planning a website as a blueprint. This is an open brief, the subject/topic of your site can be anything, i.e. it could be a portfolio, or a 'concept' site (tell a story, or be a site for a film), or an online resource, etc. A blueprint is a document that describes what you are intending to make, it defines what the site is, its intended audience, its structure and design. This document will be a multi-page portrait A4 size with one mock-up or wireframe image per page (remember to use the grids from week 6).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d9bfc2ebdbf59850eb6b147a3a9619fa","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c9bfc2ebdbf59850eb6b147a3a9619ec","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SDES3174.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES3400 - Textile Industry and Forecasting","description":"

SDES3400 Textile Industry and Forecasting develops your knowledge and experience of the textile design industry. It challenges with creative ways of developing designs and complex industry based design projects requiring innovative solutions, and involves a critical appraisal of the role of trends and forecasting on contemporary design. Project briefs cover designing for a range of industries and will include a selection from fashion, apparel, home wares, interior and / or exterior locations. Projects will involve self-selecting a preferred industry sector, allowing you to focus your design skills towards this sector and to develop expertise in their specific design requirements.


Project documentation and presentation methods are expected to reflect a substantial individual sophistication of textile design ideas, techniques, execution and realization for the specific textiles industry plus an understanding of the environmental and sustainable issues for materials, processes and use of resources involved in these sectors. 


SDES3400 Textile Industry and Forecasting and SDES3401 Smart Textiles and New Technologies are complementary 3rd year courses which, together form the two x 3000 level core studies in the Textile Design studio stream within the BDes program. Together these courses build on the skills and knowledge acquired from previous Textile Design studio stream courses and prepare you for more advanced studies in the 4000 level courses of this program. 



 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c2ae787fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961908","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 2: Social Fabric: a contemporary textile design project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

Social Fabric is a contemporary textiles project involving design for social impact and engagement. Design for this sector is firstly about people, about providing value, causing transformational change, empowering people, creating systems, minimizing wastes and expenses. It is also about management, leadership, training, education, ethics and entrepreneurship. This project is to design a range that can be produced by an artisan group or community group. You are to act as a designer who works with their knowledge and skill base to create a 'new' range that can be produced for income generation purposes. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"31ae387fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619fc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b9ae787fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961901","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c6ae787fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961904","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"35ae387fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619cd","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 1: 'rug up 2017' Designer Rugs: a contemporary design project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

Design a range of contemporary rugs for a specific client. This project gives the experience of designing a contemporary object (s) for a selected client; knowledge of trend and colour forecasting; and the impact of innovation on design parameters given by client and industry constraints.

\n

Group and peer studio discussions, individual studio consultation, written and verbal feedback. Feedback will be delivered via Review in a timely manner (no more than two weeks from the date of submission), be succinct and clear with personalized comments for each student.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"31ae387fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619fc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7dae387fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619fe","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b9ae787fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961901","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e9ae387fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c8","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SDES3400.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES3401 - Smart Textiles and New Technologies","description":"

SDES3401 Smart Textiles and New Technologies introduces a range of smart textiles, new technologies and processes developed by industry specialists including artists and designers, for textile applications in the worlds of art, fashion, design, engineering and science.


The course covers recent developments in textile fabrics, materials, structures, manufacture, technologies and processes, and acknowledges the textile traditions that these developments referenced. Areas examined will include thermoplastics, smart textiles, micro electronics, molecular nanotechnology, sustainability and green textiles, direct digital printing, new developments in man made and natural textiles properties and architectural, medical, engineering, manufacturing and sporting applications for these textiles.


The course enables you to investigate innovative textile concepts that explore the integration of the handmade with these emerging, new and smart technologies. Projects will involve research into new technologies and development of a self directed project that aligns with individual interests. 


SDES3401 Smart Textiles and New Technologies and SDES3400 Textile Industry and Forecasting are complementary 3rd year courses which, together form the two x 3000 level core studies in the Textile Design studio stream within the BDes program. Together these courses build on the skills and knowledge acquired from previous Textile Design studio stream courses and prepare you for more advanced studies in the 4000 level courses of this program. 



","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"51ae387fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96199a","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Hand and Smart Textiles : design development","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Develop an innovative design proposal that integrates hand and smart textile technologies relevant to a specific industry sector. Your design proposal must include design experimentation, consideration of functional and aesthetic properties and evaluation of processes. You are asked to summarise your design proposal in a 5min presentation given to the class. Details for Task 1 will be available on Moodle. 

\n","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8dae387fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96198d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c9ae387fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961990","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"49ae387fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96195a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Realised Hand and Smart Textiles studio project","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

Using the research and design development undertaken in Assessment 1 as a starting point, resolve and realise your innovative design that integrates hand and smart textile technologies relevant to a specific industry sector. Your final design outcome/s will be supported by a concept statement and presentation and installed as part of a public exhibition. Details for Task 2 will be available on Moodle. 

\n","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"19ae387fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961993","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"55ae387fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961996","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"81ae387fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96195f","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SDES3401.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES3402 - Second Skin: Textiles and the Body","description":"

This course investigates the intimate relationship between cloth and the body. Cloth is embedded within our very being, like a second skin it records and traces our journey from birth till death. The body and ideas of embodiment remain key conceptual concerns for many contemporary artists who utilise or make reference to textiles in their practice.


As part of this course you will research the role of the garment to cloth, cover, protect and conceal the human form. You will undertake projects that challenge the concepts of containment, the wearable, and negotiate breaking the boundaries between art and fashion. You will realise studio projects informed by this research that are conceptually driven as opposed to focusing on wearable or functional outcomes.


Studio workshops will explore a range of textile techniques and diverse approaches that experiment with surface, form, installation and display. Assessment in this course includes research tasks, workshop experimentation and realising projects that engage with the concepts developed the course. 


SDES3402 Second Skin and SDES3403 Experimental Art Textiles are complementary 3rd year courses which together form the two Level 3 core studies in the Textiles studio stream within the BFA and BMA programs. Together these courses prepare you for more advanced studies in Level 4 courses.

The artwork may also consider the body below the surface of the skin to reveal or expose an element of the human body, either visceral, psychological or emotional. Assessment includes evidence of research, documentation of samples and experiments, reflective studio journal, artist concept statement and resolved artworks.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES3403 - Experimental Art Textiles","description":"

This Experimental Art Textiles course explores the skills and knowledge needed to research and experiment with materials and processes contextualised by contemporary art practice and your own individual research interests. It allows you to propose your own independent, experimental studio research project that builds on existing knowledge, research and discoveries. 


You are asked to consider techniques and skills they have acquired alongside concepts and ideas investigated in this experimental textiles studio. This course will allow you to gain a critical understanding of your practice in order to develop rigorous new and experimental work that further expands your existing interests and concerns. 


As part of this course, lectures and workshops are designed to assist you to explore and investigate contemporary debate and approaches to in-practice (studio) research and the possibilities and challenges this presents for your own emerging practice. You are expected to experiment with a wide variety of material and technical approaches, conduct further research, develop reflective writing and presentation skills as well as participate in focused group and peer discussions. This course encourages you towards an experimental art textiles practice, to take risks in the development of the projects and to constantly push at the conceptual, material, technical and aesthetic borders.


SDES3403 Experimental Art Textiles and SDES3402 Second Skin are complementary 3rd year courses which together form the two x Level 3 core studies in the Textiles studio stream within the BFA (Hons) and BMA (Hons) programs. Together these courses prepare you for more advanced studies in Level 4 courses.

This project gives students the opportunity to propose their own independent studio research project by building on existing knowledge, research and discoveries. Students are encouraged to consider their own material language and to take risks in the development of the project, through experimentation with a wide variety of material and technical approaches, further research, analysis and discussion. Assessment to include written proposal, artists talk presentation, evidence of research, documentation of samples and experiments, reflective studio journal and artist concept statement.

This project allows you to propose your own independent studio research project by building on existing knowledge, research and discoveries. You are encouraged to consider your own material language and to take risks in the development of the project through experimentation with a wide variety of material and technical approaches, further research, analysis and discussion. Assessment to include written proposal, artists talk presentation, evidence of research, documentation of samples and experiments, reflective studio journal and artist concept statement.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0b9ef47fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96190d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"479ef47fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961910","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3a9eb47fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ff","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Experimental Textiles","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

This project asks students to review and re-visit past work produced in their first and second year as a strategy to refine their own practice. Students will critically reflect on their approach to concepts, methods and materials as a way to expand and develop their own visual language. Using physical examples of past work as starting points, students are asked to develop a self-directed studio research proposal with the aim of producing a new highly considered and innovative body of work. Assessment to include written proposal, evidence of research, documentation of samples and experiments, reflective studio journal and artist concept statement.
