Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES3404 - Ceramics: Form and Context","description":"

This course situates ceramics in the built environment and reconsiders its meaning and value within the complexity of urban infrastructure. Extending the dialogue that explores ceramics in an expanded field of art and design, you are encouraged to develop an imaginative, contextualised practice through innovative approaches to the medium applied in different professional settings.Topics include tableware and home ware design, architectural ceramics and public art.


Projects explore the expression of ideas through public awards and exhibitions that engage themes linking consumer psychology, social and environmental sustainability in the context of architecture, food, the gallery and the home. They facilitate the acquisition of higher level research, presentation and communications skills developed through visualisation, prototyping, documentation and specialised fabrication for ceramics and associated media. 


This course extends a foundation in ceramic studio practice acquired in 2000 level Ceramics courses. Emphasising cross disciplinary thinking and activity the course connects specialist areas of ceramics practice across the fields of design, media arts and fine arts. It supports students who wish to pursue ceramics as either an integrated or specialist area of study. Assessment in this course includes practical studio projects, exercises, presentation and written reports.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"799eb47fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961911","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 1: Ceramics for the Built Environment","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

For this project you will prepare and submit a proposal for a competition or award, which locates a ceramic work within the built environment. 

Competitions represent an important opportunity for emerging artists and designers to build a reputation in a professional context by presenting their ideas in a professional environment. The competition brief is a platform for you to think in interdisciplinary terms and challenge existing conceptual frameworks for Ceramics, and a forum for you to communicate ideas to a professional audience that address industry conventions. Initially you will investigate and analyse opportunities to address a nominated design or art award, then research and assess the significance of 2 visionary concepts within the context of the competition. The two concepts will be then presented as proposals to the class in a 5 minute talk accompanied by A3 storyboards that include a short written statement, a clear visual representation, a fabrication methodology and a schedule for completion. Proposals will vary depending upon the particular brief and your concept, however they should incorporate a conceptual framework, aesthetic considerations, (trans)portability, manufacturability, sustainability, durability, performance and market context. You will select, prepare and submit one of these ideas as a submission which satisfies the competition entry requirements. Your final entry should articulate the proposed idea in a 10 x A4 page document using illustrations, 3D models, renderings, diagrams and images illustrating the finished work in the proposed location. It should also include a statement of intent, dimensioned drawings, material samples and production details. Your project Journal will document your ideas and articulate your engagement with research, studio work, projects and learning activities. You will need to regularly update your journal and submit this for assessment.

Progressive verbal feedback from tutor and peers linked to set tasks plus written feedback on completed work submitted for formal assessment

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"219eb47fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96190b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"7d9eb47fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96190d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a59eb47fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961905","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"dd9e747fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ea","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 2: Objects of Influence","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

This project explores the interaction of form and meaning in the creation of ‘stuff’, specifically, shaped and graphic surfaces of ceramic objects. Both the ‘Spin the Table’ and ‘Subversive Gesture’ topics consider the theme of 'sustainable participation' through the lens of propaganda, reflecting on the historical role of Agitprop ceramics in the Bolshevik revolution. Your task is to address the theme by designing a table-scape, art or design work of contemporary social significance, accompanied by a ‘manifesto’ which outlines the position, context and specifications for the work. You will progressively explore the topic of your choice, develop and refine a body of ceramic work appropriate for exhibition and work as a group to present this for assessment at the course conclusion.

Verbal feedback in class from tutor and peers plus written feedback on submitted work available from an assessment rubric via email or accessed from the Review Assessment Website.

contentlets.keywords: design studies,ceramics,design,model making,plaster,space,computer aided design,digital fabrication,architecture,tableware,exhibition,commission,public art,public design,manufacturing,community,sustainability,moulding and casting,communication
contentlets.description:
This course situates ceramics in the built environment and reconsiders its meaning and value within the complexity of urban infrastructure. Extending the dialogue that explores ceramics in an expanded field of art and design, you are encouraged to develop an imaginative, contextualised practice through innovative approaches to the medium applied in different professional settings.Topics include tableware and home ware design, architectural ceramics and public art.

Projects explore the expression of ideas through public awards and exhibitions that engage themes linking consumer psychology, social and environmental sustainability in the context of architecture, food, the gallery and the home. They facilitate the acquisition of higher level research, presentation and communications skills developed through visualisation, prototyping, documentation and specialised fabrication for ceramics and associated media. 

This course extends a foundation in ceramic studio practice acquired in 2000 level Ceramics courses. Emphasising cross disciplinary thinking and activity the course connects specialist areas of ceramics practice across the fields of design, media arts and fine arts. It supports students who wish to pursue ceramics as either an integrated or specialist area of study. Assessment in this course includes practical studio projects, exercises, presentation and written reports.
contentlets.title: Ceramics: Form and Context

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES3405 - Ceramics: Interactive Artefacts","description":"

This studio-based course extends a foundation in ceramic studio practice acquired in 2000 level Ceramics courses, with a focus on supporting students to research and develop methods and approaches relevant to directions they are wishing to explore as emerging creative practioners interested in working with cermaics. Students explore ways in which identity, meaning and value are embodied in the shape, appearance and materiality of ceramic objects and related contexts of use and appreciation.


Supported by an analysis of historic and contemporary forms and practices related to their individual interests, students develop a body of work that synthesizes and re-interprets their historical research, towards an articulation of the significance the practice they are developing within the context of contemporary art/design/maker discourses.


Assessment in this course includes practical studio projects, presentations and written reports.


 


 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"83bcad77dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619d5","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"In-Studio Exhibition of Selected Works, and Interpretive Materials","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"65","description":"

This assessment requires you to conclude your semester's research with an in-studio display of completed ceramic work, that provides evidence of the development and refinement of of your studio-based investigations.

This resolved body-of-work or work, should be of a refined, professional standard and demonstrate your capacity to engage rigorously with the diversity of activities that constitute ‘studio' and scholarly research, specific to contemporary design practice. It should also indicate a sophisticated understanding of the role of context, audience, display and interpretative materials. 

The exhibited work must be accompanied by 2 components:

1. A journal that documents and reflects on, week-by-week, the research, development and evaluation of your ideas, processes and experiments.

2. An interpretive text (between 300 minimum and 500 words maximum) that communicates in 'plain English' the ideas you have explored, the contexts relevant to your work/research, and ways in which this practice responds to some aspect of contemporary culture and/or society.  Present a hardcopy this text allongside the display of your work, and include a copy of this text in your journal.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4bbcad77dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ce","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"87bcad77dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619d1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c7bcad77dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619a6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"32bcad77dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96199d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Presentation: Historical Research & Preliminary Studies (green-ware)","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"35","description":"

For this assessment, you are required to investigate human interactions with ceramic objects as ‘artefacts’ – that invite a consideration of the life, values and culture from which it was made; through experimentation with interactive texts, images, and/or sounds to facilitate interpretations of your ceramic objects (artefacts).

This task involves an intertwining of on-line research, with hands-on, clay-forming processes.

Research examples of ceramic objects and other practices or artefacts, related in some way to the kinds of forms and processes, that you are interested and able to explore.

Your visual and historical research needs to encompass at least three different examples/inspirations from across a period of at least 1000-years with at least one ‘contemporary’ example, reflecting on similarities and differences between the different approaches and contexts that these objects and practices emerged from.

Before your presentation, discuss with your peers and tutor, what these objects and practices can tell us about the values and beliefs of the people who made these objects, ways that they were used or appreciated at various times in history, and how they are relevant to the kinds of forms and values you want to explore with the objects you want to making for this course.

For each historical precedent you consider, make a prototype object that explores in some way, some aspect of the example you have chosen, for example it’s shape, it’s texture, it’s symbolism/iconography. Document and reflect on the objects you have made, and how they are helping you better understand the direction you are seeking to explore.

This subject explores the design of visual identity and branding strategies across different media used to connect producers and consumers. visual identity and branding are considered within a range of graphic studio models in which designers work. A client brief provides you with the opportunity to explore how design strategically addresses the branding issues of local small to medium enterprises, national and international organisations, audiences and contexts. Reflecting on a range of contemporary models of design practice provides you with the opportunity to develop a portfolio that showcases your design approach in relation to industry practice and possible futures.

\n

Studio tutorial and peer verbal feedback throughout the semester with written feedback in an assessment rubric via email.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES3407 - Graphics Media: Data Visualisation, Interactives and Wayfinding","description":"

The complexity of information and data density has increased with the growth of digital graphic media formats. This subject explores strategies for the design and navigation of visual information for interactive and spatial design contexts. A range of multi-dimensional spaces in which graphic designers provide navigation cues will be considered from the perspectives of content, context and purpose. The subject invites you to engage with the design of emerging graphic media and the principles of universal design for improved accessibility.


Assessment in this course includes projects that engage with emerging graphic forms, for example; data visualisation, mobile phone applications, website design, and wayfinding programs.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"3a47a9f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961924","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Visualising Ocean Change","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Assessment 1 invites you to design an innovative, interactive exhibition piece communicating the urgency of issues of Ocean Change. The exhibition piece will be based on the visualisation of three different pieces of data.

Your brief is to design an exhibition piece that communicates about specific issues contributing to Ocean Change and the resultant effects using data visualisation. Your audience is the general public who would see, experience and interact with your design in the context of an exhibition.

In Week 2, a verbal presentation (3-5 min max) supported by up to 5 slides (16:9 PDF format) will identify the issue related to the Ocean Change and accompanying data that you will focus on. Your presentation will discuss potential design strategies for a data / information-based exhibition piece. You will receive formative tutor feedback in class on this presentation to guide the development of your project.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3a47a9f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961911","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3e47a9f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961920","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ae4769f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619fd","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"A Wayfinding System for UNSW Art & Design","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

Assessment task 2 invites Graphics Media students to design a new wayfinding system for the UNSW Art & Design campus.

The client (UNSW Art & Design) requires an innovative Graphics Media response to the problem of wayfinding around the campus. The response to this site-specific brief must contain consistent directional elements designed to orientate faculty, students and visitors from the street perimeter of the campus, to individual buildings and facilities, and then the respective floors and rooms of the buildings without confusion. It should include methodologies for locating and signposting studios, workshops, library, administrative departments, learning commons, research labs, makerspace, and other facilities and services such as the library, lecture theatre and toilets.

The wayfinding system must utilise key elements of UNSW branding system (the visitor should know that they are on a UNSW site), but you are strongly encouraged to develop a distinctive, experimental, and interactive approach that reflects the nature of the campus and the art and design programs at UNSW Art & Design in both our education and research areas. Your design concept must apply human-centred universal design principles, such as accessibility, that are appropriate to all users of the campus.

A campus mapping presentation (16:9 PDF format) that outlines your understanding of the campus wayfinding challenges and opportunities will be presented for formative feedback in week 2. How does the user interact with this site? You should include entry points, existing signage, navigation problems, opportunities, potential interactivity and visual reference.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES3408 - Jewellery Installation and Jewellery for the Table","description":"

Jewellery Installation and Jewellery for the Table focuses on the design of contemporary jewellery objects for installation in space and as functional objects designed for the table. This course encourages students to challenge their understanding of jewellery by engaging in a series of guided tasks that are framed and contextualised by Contemporary Jewellery and Object Practice. Students will develop a body of work in response to diverse client briefs.


This course will extend your previous examination of three-dimensional forms focusing on systems that allow for the production of objects both worn by the body and engaging with spaces. Students will work with a variety of materials, applying jewellery skills to small-scale production. Through experimentation with materials and a range of jewellery processes, students will be able to selectively expand their conceptual approach to produce a body of work. Assessment in this course includes studio research tasks and projects designed to build a portfolio to showcase the capacity to respond to a client brief design in preparation for possible futures.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"549e747fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961918","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 1: "Dwelling" Research Task","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

This course is expressed through three staged assessment tasks each stage is in response to a client brief and requires you to develop over the semester, design proposals, concept models & finished works for a specified site. Task 1 requires you to Research, Analyse, Summarise and Propose a Solution, and assemble a written response to a Client Brief which includes, Research and Analysis, and Design Proposal for “Body, Building, Table”. 

Compile a report on one of the selected Peter Stutchbury Houses summarising the significant qualities of the house and in response develop a design proposal for the construction of a site-specific work for this house. The proposed work may be intended as a wearable (body) as an intervention or installation in the space (building) or a functional object specifically for the table of this house. 

Student feedback will be based on Studio presentation, Studio Discussion, verbal and written feedback.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"149e347fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ef","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4c9e347fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619e6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"889e347fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619e9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c49e347fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ec","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2f8e347fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961970","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 2: Implements for Dinner Table Use: A Series of Three Metal Concept Models.","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Assessment Brief: Jewellery Installation and Jewellery for the Table focuses on the design of contemporary jewellery objects for installation in space and as functional objects designed for the table.

Building on your research from Task 1, you are asked to work through a design process to develop Three Metal Concept Models that summarise your response to your selected Peter Stutchbury House. Students are required to apply a personal Concept (developed from the research in Task 1) for ideas generation and create a family of objects using metal fabrication techniques and processes. Jewellery Studio Technical Experiments will involve guided materials experimentation, thinking and design speculation and progress through to the design and making of a finished family of related jewellery/objects. The Models that will allow you to experiment and to articulate your ideas based on a selected work of your client.

Students will receive both written and verbal feedback

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4c9e347fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619e6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c49e347fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ec","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"778e347fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961975","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 3: "Body, Building, Table"","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"45","description":"

Students are required to make their approved Prototype Object or Objects for the client Peter Stutchbury Architects. Based on the House they have selected students are required to design and create site-specific works for this building. The works may be functional for example for the table or an ornamental security screen or they may take the form of an installation in your chosen space. The finished object must be supported by a document that records the design process and clearly states the context for the submission.

Students will receive both written and verbal feedback

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES3409 - Jewellery: Contextual Issues through Bodyworks","description":"

This advanced course extends your jewellery skills and knowledge by increasing the complexity of studio practice within the jewellery discipline through studio-based activities and rigorous critical analysis. This course contributes to the jewellery stream by developing your knowledge, skill and understanding of designing contemporary wearable jewellery. You will focus on contemporary jewellery in a way that challenges what contemporary jewellery can be, the relationships between jewellery and the body, and the nature of a jewellery wearable. Self-direction will be encouraged so that you acquire and apply skills in developing and articulating a brief.


This course engages students in a series of preparatory workshops, to introduce materials and processes suitable for the finished work or series of works for Assessment Task 3: Bodyworks. Studio tasks will offer guided materials experimentation, thinking and design speculation through both technical and conceptual based studio classes under the broad heading of ‘Surface and Colour, Material Language.’


Three Assessment tasks over the Semester will address the conceptual, material and technical understanding of Jewellery and Object Design as applied to the body, and may require in some instances for you to liaise with industry partners in the development of your design solutions. Project documentation and presentation methods are expected to reflect a substantial sophistication of design ideas and communication and be supported by relevant practical and written research.


SDES3409 - Jewellery: Contextual Issues through Bodyworks is an advanced 3000 level studio course. It is one of a suite of two (or more) interrelated core courses in Year 3 that complete a four-course specialist 'stream' in the BFA(Hons), BMA(Hons) and/or BDes(Hons) programs in Year 3.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"aa8ef07fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ac","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Bodyworks – Wearable Work","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Assessment Task 3 requires the design and production of a wearable work, or a small series of works in response to the concept developed in AT2. The design of this wearable builds on your earlier research and analysis, and extends your concept through further testing, sampling and prototyping before proceeding to the finished work/s. The finished work/s must be supported by a set of three images printed on postcards that record your design and clearly contextualise your work on and off the body. The postcards and the finished work/s are to be seen as gallery ready.

A gallery-ready work or series of works relating to the theme Bodyworks

3 professionally printed postcards

200 word written statement about the work/s

Ongoing, regular documentation of progress and development of your work and research on Jewel Blog

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"268ef07fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619a3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"628ef07fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619a6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9a8ef07fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96199d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1e8ef07fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961987","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Bodyworks – The Conceptual Body","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Identify and research the practice of at least two contemporary jewellery practitioners whose practice focusses on large scale, conceptual approaches to bodywork (this may include performance and installation). Provide an overview of each artist’s background and an analysis of the relationship of the wearable to the body in their practice, citing at least three examples of their work. Produce a concept board with images of at least three examples of the artist’s work accompanied by a brief written analysis of the relationship of the wearable to the body in their practice.

Discuss your proposed Bodyworks project noting how the selected examples of work have informed your ideas. (Concept statement)

At least 3 detailed drawings of your proposed work noting scale (measurements), materials, processes. 

A3 concept board

Captioned images (at least 6 images – 3 per artist discussed)

Written analysis 300 words

3 Drawings of proposed work

Oxford style referencing – footnotes

Bibliography

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"268ef07fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619a3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"628ef07fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619a6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"ae8ef07fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619a8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8a8ef07fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96197e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Bodyworks – Surface & Colour, Material Language","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Continuing on from your research undertaken in AT1, this assessment invites you to explore these ideas in your own work to develop your own conceptual approach to the idea of Bodyworks underpinned by the conceptual issues connected without understanding of the body and wearables. Your work should resonate with the notion of large scale, conceptual approaches to bodywork (this may include performance and installation).

You will undertake extensive material and conceptual research, investigating 2 non-metal materials and conducting a series of 10 technical experiments using metal.  This material and technical exploration supports the experimentation and development of 3 refined Concept Models that reference and develop your concept for Assessment 3 “ Bodyworks – Wearable Work”

Your technical and conceptual explorations should be accompanied by thorough documentation in a process journal. The non-metal materials you select should have a conceptual resonance with your proposed work for Assessment 3. This introduction to rigorous studio-based conceptual, material and technical research is intended to support the development of your own independent approach to studio-based design practice. 

Ongoing, regular documentation of the progress and development of your work and research on Jewel Blog

Three refined concept models

10 technical experiments

Investigations into 2 non-metal material

A Process Journal

contentlets.keywords: design studies,bodyworks,contemporary jewellery,charms,wearables,art jewellery
contentlets.description:
This advanced course extends your jewellery skills and knowledge by increasing the complexity of studio practice within the jewellery discipline through studio-based activities and rigorous critical analysis. This course contributes to the jewellery stream by developing your knowledge, skill and understanding of designing contemporary wearable jewellery. You will focus on contemporary jewellery in a way that challenges what contemporary jewellery can be, the relationships between jewellery and the body, and the nature of a jewellery wearable. Self-direction will be encouraged so that you acquire and apply skills in developing and articulating a brief.

This course engages students in a series of preparatory workshops, to introduce materials and processes suitable for the finished work or series of works for Assessment Task 3: Bodyworks. Studio tasks will offer guided materials experimentation, thinking and design speculation through both technical and conceptual based studio classes under the broad heading of ‘Surface and Colour, Material Language.’

Three Assessment tasks over the Semester will address the conceptual, material and technical understanding of Jewellery and Object Design as applied to the body, and may require in some instances for you to liaise with industry partners in the development of your design solutions. Project documentation and presentation methods are expected to reflect a substantial sophistication of design ideas and communication and be supported by relevant practical and written research.

SDES3409 - Jewellery: Contextual Issues through Bodyworks is an advanced 3000 level studio course. It is one of a suite of two (or more) interrelated core courses in Year 3 that complete a four-course specialist 'stream' in the BFA(Hons), BMA(Hons) and/or BDes(Hons) programs in Year 3.
contentlets.title: Jewellery: Contextual Issues through Bodyworks

This specialist course extends knowledge of materials and processes and their relationship to experiential lighting design through adaptive/responsive design scenarios. Emphasis is placed on theories related to experiential lighting design. Project briefs will introduce the notion of the client, manufacturer and end-user. You are expected to liaise with industry in order to fabricate a  full-scale working prototype of your design. A series of case studies exemplifying design research, production/technology methodologies including laser cutting and sheet forming and fabrication will be undertaken. You will engage in problem solving by creatively exploring the relationship between the human interface (experience) and lighting design. Communication techniques in both 2D and 3D format will be extended on from the 2000 stream, including an opportunity to work with a pre-developed arduino module (hardware plus software). You will collaborate in the design and installation of your prototypes in a public exhibition.


You will work on one project throughout the course and have three sequential assessment tasks covering; research and concepts, design development and final design synthesis and presentation.


SDES3410 Object Design: Industry Connections is an advanced 3000 level studio course. It is one of a suite of two interrelated core courses in Year 3 that complete a four-course specialist 'object stream' in the BDes(Hons) program in Year 3.

This assessment task will a report on your research responding to a detailed project brief that will be posted on the Moodle. The report will include presentation and discussion of concepts, context and precedents for your design, and will illustrate concept models by photographic and diagrammatic representation.

Students will receive written feedback on their report, along with grades for this task in class, and accessible online via Review. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ad8ef07fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961942","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f98ef07fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961945","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"118ef07fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96190b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 2: Lighting Design Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

In this assessment task you will propose a resolved design in the form of 2D and 3D representation, technical drawing and information from industry sources. Details will be placed on the the Moodle. 

Students will receive written feedback on their design development work and presentation, along with grades for this task in class, and accessible online via Review. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"398ef07fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961948","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ad8ef07fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961942","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f98ef07fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961945","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"218ef07fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96191c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 3: Lighting Scale Prototype","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

In this assessment task you will a full-scale prototype responding to the project brief and supported by computer rendering, photography and other forms of documentation, plus written and verbal explanation. Details to be provided on the Moodle.

Students will recieve written feedback along with grades provided by their tutor, and accessible online via Review.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES3411 - Object as Activist: Furniture Design & the Community","description":"

Object as Activist: Furniture Design and the Community aims to engage you in the field of furniture design for social impact and innovation. Studio briefs will be framed around 'socially active design', where the focus of the design is society and its transition and/or transformation to a more sustainable way of living, working and producing. Research will be driven by real life problems identified by local Councils, non-govenment organisations or agencies addressing community wellbeing. You will learn how to write a return brief, engage with community and develop an understanding of your role as a 'change agent' for society. Design outcomes for this studio will be framed by your response to the brief.


You will work on one project throughout the course and have three sequential assessment tasks covering; research and concepts, design development and final design synthesis and presentation.


SDES3411 Object as Activist: Furniture Design and the Community is a 3000 level studio course. It is one of a suite of two interrelated core courses in Year 3 that complete a four-course specialist 'object stream' in the BDes(Hons) programs in Year 3.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e48eb07fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961970","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Design Development","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Develop a presentation summarising your design proposal in response to the brief, informed by your studio experimentation, concepting, sketching, models and prototypes etc, plus a supporting text or diagrams referencing your secondary research and understanding of theory as needed.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"508eb07fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961967","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9c8eb07fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961969","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d88eb07fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96196c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"048eb07fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961956","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

A final presentation of your object design in response to the Brief. The object should be presented the form of a protoype or a proposal of equivalent resolution and supported by process documentation, iterative desigh development documentation including sketching ahd models, technical drawings, video or photography, and/or contextual or scenario studies. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"148eb07fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961964","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"508eb07fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961967","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9c8eb07fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961969","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d88eb07fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96196c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4c8eb07fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96195a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research and Design Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

You are asked to prepare an illustrated paper responding to the Brief and synthesising your understanding of an object and its materiality, context and use, with design and sustainability theory. Summarise this paper in a slide presentation in class.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"148eb07fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961964","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"cc8eb07fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96191f","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SDES3411.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES3412 - Spatial Design: Visualising Virtual Spaces","description":"

This course is intended to develop your skills in the design and visualisation of virtual spaces with a focus on their applications in the fields of urban and landscape design, architecture, interior design, and heritage studies. To explore the possibilities of virtual space you will reconstruct and reconfigure virtual heritage environments-the phantom structures of the past-and also design the kinds of fantasy spaces that can only exist in the digital realm. You will develop skills in the design of virtual 3D models and learn to produce flythroughs and photorealistic visualisations using programs such as Vectorworks, Photoshop, and associated rendering software. Assessment is based on your demonstrated ability to design virtual spaces and produce 2D representations that inform, excite and delight. The course is one of two 3000-level courses in the spatial design studio stream. It may also be taken as an elective, subject to availability and the completion of 2000-level courses in the spatial design stream.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"0f7e707fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961980","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 1:Vocabulary of Space","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Task one provides students an opportunity to explore the vocabulary of space, and develop skills in applying the vocabulary of space to examine and interpret the selected precedent's work. 

Assessment includes Research, Conceptual Development, Design Development and Presentation.

Verbal peer and tutor feedback during development phase in studio; written self- and peer assessment on submission; written tutor feedback according to a criterion matrix correlated to the learning outcomes set out above and communicated electronically within two weeks of submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"4b7e707fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961970","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"cf7e707fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96196a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"727e707fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961933","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 2: De/reconstruction","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Drawing the inspiration of ‘Form, Space, and Order’ from the book of Francis Ching, students will study the general principles of construction and de-construction of space and form, through exploring some fundamental ways of manipulating / organizing the vocabulary of space for a real and virtual environment. Students will create new space / form of a structure / building by 3D model. 

Verbal peer and tutor feedback during development phase in studio; written self- and peer assessment on submission; written tutor feedback according to a criterion matrix correlated to the learning outcomes set out above and communicated electronically within two weeks of submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"4b7e707fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961970","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"cf7e707fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96196a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ba7e707fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961937","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 3: Nine-Square Matrix","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Drawing the essence of the outcomes of the studio task one and two, students will explore key issues of spatial design related to simplicity and complexity, proportion and scale, and making sets of relationships between parts and the whole, interior and exterior. Students will design and construct a three-dimensional composition of spaces for each combination of floors, walls and roofs at each level of complexity that are identified in the nine-square matrix. Students will document the space with plans, sections, and perspectives by drawings and computer work.

Verbal peer and tutor feedback during development phase in studio; written self- and peer assessment on submission; written tutor feedback according to a criterion matrix correlated to the learning outcomes set out above and communicated electronically within two weeks of submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0f7e707fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96196d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"4b7e707fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961970","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"cf7e707fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96196a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f27e707fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96193c","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SDES3412.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

honours).","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"SDES3413","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES3413 - Spatial Design and Documentation: Structures and Surfaces","description":"

In this course, you will extend your knowledge and skills of spatial design by learning how to design and document small-scale interiors for activities such as food preparation and consumption, personal hygiene, sleeping, and leisure. In studio classes, you will explore innovative responses to client briefs that you will be required to resolve to a level of detail that includes structures, fittings, surface finishes and lighting systems.  Documenting your designs with construction drawings, material boards, and expressive images of the designed space, you will also learn how to cost your designs and work within real world administrative and regulatory constraints associated with building design in Australia. The course is one of two 3000-level courses in the spatial design studio stream. It may be taken as an elective, subject to availability and the completion of 2000-level courses in the stream.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"ea3f30ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c9","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Concept and Design Development","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

In Assessment 2, you will further develop your work from Task 1 and engage in concept generation and development. You need to create innovative design ideas that convincingly respond to your developed project brief and the identified problems.

The Project proposal is to be summarized in 1 X A1 board (portrait) poster. This needs to be pinned up in the studio class, and accompanied by a your research journal, conceptual drawings, and mock-up models in response to the personalized project brief. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2a3f30ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"da3f30ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"023f30ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96198d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Presentation and Documentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"45","description":"

In Asssessment 3, you will develop your final design solutions. You need to create and present resolved material design solutions as synthesized, physical and image-based representations, which can clearly and convincingly communicate a design project at an advanced level.  

The finished design work will include all of your project documentation, in the form of an A3 project report with design drafting documentation, A1 size poster(s), 3D physical model, computer work, etc. This should be presented at the assigned time in the room scheduled for your project assessment. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2a3f30ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"da3f30ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5a3f30ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961991","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Response to the Brief","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

In Assessment 1, you will research a design issue framed by your specified / selected site or theme that lies within the scope and context of the project brief. You need to critically develop the given open-ended project brief by thoroughly researching, analysing and synthesising multiple contextual factors that relate to your site / theme. A detailed and personalized return-brief needs to be generated at an advanced and reflective level.  

Your project research is to be summarized in 6 x A3 size posters, and a developed project brief (2 x A3 size posters). Refer to Moodle for the expanded brief.

You will have an informal pin-up session in Week 3 where you will discuss your work and receive feedback in studio group critiques and you will then submit your work online by Friday of Week 3.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2a3f30ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9e3f30ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c63f30ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961988","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SDES3413.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"SDES3414","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES3414 - Integrated Project","description":"

Integrated Project is a culminating interdisciplinary Design course that encourages you to draw together insights and expertise from two or more specialisations within Design, or Design coupled with another approved creative/professional discipline. You will investigate a given situation or design context in response to nominated themes, issues or set of conditions specified in a socially-engaged design brief.


The course models professional studio practices by focusing on how designers and design function in society. You will work collaboratively in teams of people with different skill sets, drawing on a wide range of available knowledge and skills to produce an informed return brief, which is supported by relevant research, concept and material explorations. In order to realise project options for final presentation, the resulting Design solutions will integrate the needs of end users, identify and address constraints as well as syntehesise two or more fields of creative expertise to generate potentially unique and innovative ideas and outcomes.


Assessment in this course is based on submission and evaluation of a three stage project development process including:


1. Return brief and conceptual idea generation


2. Iterative design development examining possible solutions


3. Project contribution evidenced in final presentation


This course is available to all Year 3 BDes(Hons), BFA(Hons) and BMA(Hons) students studying one or more Design studios. You can take it either as an alternative to one of your Year 3 studio courses in Ceramic Design, Jewellery, Graphics Media, Spatial Design, Object Design and Textile Design, or choose it as an Elective in addition to completing your one or two 4-course Design studios. 


To enrol in this Level 3 course you must have previously completed two related Level 2 courses in at least one Design studio at Art & Design, or the equivalent in another approved field of creative / professional endeavour.

contentlets.keywords: design studies,design challenge,integrated project,socially engaged design  practices,applied design research,contemporary design
contentlets.description:
Integrated Project is a culminating interdisciplinary Design course that encourages you to draw together insights and expertise from two or more specialisations within Design, or Design coupled with another approved creative/professional discipline. You will investigate a given situation or design context in response to nominated themes, issues or set of conditions specified in a socially-engaged design brief.

The course models professional studio practices by focusing on how designers and design function in society. You will work collaboratively in teams of people with different skill sets, drawing on a wide range of available knowledge and skills to produce an informed return brief, which is supported by relevant research, concept and material explorations. In order to realise project options for final presentation, the resulting Design solutions will integrate the needs of end users, identify and address constraints as well as syntehesise two or more fields of creative expertise to generate potentially unique and innovative ideas and outcomes.

Assessment in this course is based on submission and evaluation of a three stage project development process including:

1. Return brief and conceptual idea generation

2. Iterative design development examining possible solutions

3. Project contribution evidenced in final presentation

This course is available to all Year 3 BDes(Hons), BFA(Hons) and BMA(Hons) students studying one or more Design studios. You can take it either as an alternative to one of your Year 3 studio courses in Ceramic Design, Jewellery, Graphics Media, Spatial Design, Object Design and Textile Design, or choose it as an Elective in addition to completing your one or two 4-course Design studios. 

To enrol in this Level 3 course you must have previously completed two related Level 2 courses in at least one Design studio at Art & Design, or the equivalent in another approved field of creative / professional endeavour.
contentlets.title: Integrated Project

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES3801 - Special Project","description":"

This course enables undergraduate students to undertake an approved 'Special Project' as part of their academic program. SDES 3801 'Special Project' courses are proposed by the School of Design Studies, COFA and are available to undergraduate students as an elective or general education course. 

A 'Special Project' involves specific, one off opportunities that may arise, which will benefit an individual student or groups of students, including participation in scheduled industry, professional community or other design related activities. This includes supervised international experiences (such as a study tour;  exhibition participation or attendance; specific workshops or courses with leading designers etc) or special projects such as professional practice in the context of specific events (eg National or International Biennales, Design conferences, festivals, events  or competitions etc) or the opportunity to undertake an individual project in conjunction with an academic within the University, for example. Course content, focus and outcomes of specific projects may be individually negotiated or may be established and repeated periodically, depending on the nature of the 'Special Project' and the interest and availability of groups of students at a particular time. 


A generic Course Outline for SDES 3801 is available from the UNSW Online Handbook. Specific course outlines will be written and distributed for each 'Special Project' offered. These will detail the academic content, objectives, assessment criteria, modes of teaching and learning, expectations and requirements of student participation appropriate for the event or proposal.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES4205 - Information Graphics: Design and Visualising Data","description":"

This course examines the issues which affect the communication and presentation of information in disciplines which employ text, data and graphics. With the advent of discoveries, inventions and improvements in computer and communication technologies our society is increasingly being expected to deal and cope with vast amounts of information in the form of text and images, as well as sound, in the case of multimedia applications. The dissemination of information can now be achieved much faster than traditional print media via the digital environment. Access to the processing and promulgation of information is also made possible through the availability of computer equipment and software packages which are now priced reasonably within the financial reach of many individuals. This democratisation of information access has produced a profound impact on how information is being generated, packaged and communicated to society. The increased proliferation of unintelligible and uncommunicable information in both the print and electronic media, and cyberspace is a pertinent case in point. These issues will be explored in a series of lectures and tutorials which examine theory, methodology and case studies.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"717e307fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619bc","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Instruction Graphics for Domestic Tasks","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

The aim of this assessment is to research and analyse the communication of illustrated instructions in print media or screen-based applications. This is followed by the generation of concepts and design proposals – informed by the application of theories of data organisation and principles of visualising data – for illustrated instructions on domestic tasks. Groups will select one domestic cleaning case study from three scenarios for development.

The final outcome is an A4 page of illustrations and typographic instructions which demonstrates a system for organising typographic and pictorial elements in the A4 instruction sheet, and a rationale for the design.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"297e307fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"757e307fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e97e307fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"217e307fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96199a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Organising and Communicating Health Information","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

The aim of this assessment task is to research and analyse the communication of health information in printed A4-size flyers, which are freely available from doctors’ surgeries, medical centres and pharmacies. This is followed by the generation of concepts and proposals – based on understanding and application of theory of data organisation, and principles of visualising data  – for redesigning a selected health information flyer. The final outcome is a redesigned health information flyer which demonstrates a system for organising typographic and pictorial elements in the flyer, and a rationale for the design. 

This assessment task involves group work. Students will work in groups of 4 to produce the final outcome – a redesigned health flyer and rationale.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"297e307fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"757e307fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ad7e307fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619af","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e97e307fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"d57e307fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961995","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SDES4205.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"SDES9203","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES9203 - Entrepreneurship, Innovation and Creativity","description":"

This course provides an understanding of the various definitions of entrepreneurship, innovation and creativity and how they intersect, influence and are shaped by designers. Creativity tools and different models of thinking are examined from a theoretical and real world perspective, to provide students with knowledge and practical techniques to help develop their careers.


Entrepreneurship takes many forms in different organisations and industries, and this course demonstrates the interconnectedness between new creative ideas, innovations, design thinking methods, and the various components needed to become an entrepreneur. Personal traits, different working environments, and various creative processes combine to enhance innovative idea development, and this is critically explored in the course content. Through lectures, tutorials, case studies and active learning in assessed coursework, students will engage with examples of entrepreneurial innovation, and develop their own creative capacity.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"552f7cbfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961996","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Innovation Research and Development","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Picking one possible response from your first report (Assessment Task 1), document how you:

i) Develop some hypotheses about appropriate design interventions

ii) Do some rapid social research in relation to your problem-solution

iii) Trial and evaluate a series of low-fi prototypes against your hypotheses

iv) Critically reflect on the process

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"192f7cbfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961980","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"912f7cbfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961986","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"092f7cbfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961972","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Entrepreneurial Strategic Plan","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Picking one possible response from your second report (Assessment Task 2), document how you would:

i) Design an organization that could sustain the creation of value around your innovation, including

a. Branding

b. Mission

c. Business Model

d. Workplace culture (profiles of staff, workday experience)

e. Precedents

Your report should validate your choices by comparisons with two to three existing examples of design entrepreneurship.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"192f7cbfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961980","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"552f7cbfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961983","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"412f7cbfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961977","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Creative Problem Finding and Reframing","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

This first assignment is an opportunity for you to experiment with a range of ideational techniques that you will be taught in the lectures and tutorials. The task requires you to work hard at being creative beyond initial biases, and critically reflect on that work. The aim is to develop as many richly creative ideas as possible, and for you to develop the habits of always generating and recording new ideas.

 Produce a report documenting how you:

i)        Find at least ten problems in everyday life worth solving

ii)       Pick 3 problems from your list of 10 and respond to them using at least 3 creativity techniques (discussed in lectures), including:

• Randomization

• Transformation Lists

• Deconstructing Problem Statements

• Systems Conflict Maps

• Visioning

iii)      Critically reflect on the process

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"192f7cbfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961980","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"912f7cbfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961986","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"cd2f7cbfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96196d","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SDES9203.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"SDES9204","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES9204 - Design Studio: Insight, Processes and Communication","description":"

This course is the foundation core studio in the Master of Design where you will deepen your understanding of the relevance of, and implications for, design in a social and environmental context. You will engage in creative strategies that extend your abilities to develop design insights to inform design solutions and impactful design practices. Reflecting the integrated nature of contemporary design across a wide variety of fields and practices, this course introduces a transdisciplinary approach to design that will be developed in subsequent core studios. You will critically analyse your design process and outcomes to develop an awareness of the agency of design in responding to broader issues, placing design as a critical practice in a broader context. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"3037fb26dbd0e410be4672f5f3961958","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Insights and Impact","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"60","description":"

Design insights help reveal underlying behaviours, relationships and patterns in your research that will inform meaningful design outcomes. In this assessment task you are asked to develop two design insights from your research responding to ‘Assessment Task 1  Stimulus’, to inform a design solution that will connect people to nature and protect the environment, through education. You will need to articulate your design solution by crafting a high-fidelity tangible model in suitable materials to communicate the design outcome. You will present the tangible model of your design solution in your scheduled class, with a brief verbal summary of how the two design insights have informed your design outcome. To document your work, you will submit a designed document that includes your two design insights and photographs of your design solution.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3037fb26dbd0e410be4672f5f396195a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3437fb26dbd0e410be4672f5f3961959","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"bc37fb26dbd0e410be4672f5f39619d6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7037fb26dbd0e410be4672f5f39619df","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Impact and Agency","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Design an A3 poster that visually represents the impact of your design solution through the application of the Bronfenbrenner’s Ecological Systems Model that you will be introduced to in the course. Your model should identify how you have considered the impact of your design on each of the five levels; microsystem (immediate environment), mesosystem (connections), exosystem (indirect environment), macrosystem (social and cultural), and chronosystem (changes over time).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3437fb26dbd0e410be4672f5f3961959","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"bc37fb26dbd0e410be4672f5f39619d6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b037fb26dbd0e410be4672f5f39619d8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Reflective Practices Leading to Insights - Milestone Activity","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"0","weighting":"0","description":"

You will respond to three of the prescribed topics of your choice from the list provided. This activity will enable you to develop meaningful design insights that will be employed in assessment task 1. The activity also acts as a milestone for formative feedback before the consensus date. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3037fb26dbd0e410be4672f5f396195a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b837fb26dbd0e410be4672f5f39619dc","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SDES9204.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"SDES9210","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES9210 - Critical Approaches to Design Practice","description":"

This course builds upon your knowledge of transdisciplinary design in social and environmental contexts through design practice as a form of discourse and innovation. You will build knowledge and understanding of design problems through evaluation and analysis to deconstruct an existing real-world object or service, and produce a critical design response. You will engage with a range of human-centred research methodologies that will aid in your selection and analysis of a design problem. Taking a transdisciplinary approach to design you will develop innovative, informed and often unexpected design solutions that further challenge conventions and assumptions. This course fosters the development of a peer mentoring culture through iteration, interdisciplinary collaboration and critique.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"5ab11b8ddb1ce01055a93324f396190b","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Project Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

This assessment task focuses on defining a research problem through critical analysis using human-centred research methodologies. Prepare a design project proposal for an everyday, real world object or service of your choosing. You will analyse the object or service using one of the research approaches provided in the course material, or from your independent study of other critical approaches. You will describe the nature of your item, including a brief background and context. You will then describe the approach and method/s that you used to analyse and deconstruct the item and its associated uses and contexts. Lastly, you will outline findings that you discern as relevant to a potential design solution. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5eb1db8ddb1ce01055a93324f3961905","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"92b11b8ddb1ce01055a93324f396190e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"96b11b8ddb1ce01055a93324f396190d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9ab11b8ddb1ce01055a93324f396190e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2eb1db8ddb1ce01055a93324f396190c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Project Design","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

In this assessment task, you will create a design response to the problem outlined in your Assessment Task 1 Proposal, with effective documentation of the outcome and processes. Your design should suggest a meaningful, engaging experience that will help transform the way they perceive or act towards the problem you identified. Your design work will be documented as a PDF with accompanying research statement describing how your design practice and outcomes address the problem/s you identified, and relevant extracts from visual diary demonstrating practice. You will also present your final design outcome in a concise oral presentation, highlighting key aspects.  

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5eb1db8ddb1ce01055a93324f3961905","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"92b11b8ddb1ce01055a93324f396190e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"96b11b8ddb1ce01055a93324f396190d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9ab11b8ddb1ce01055a93324f396190e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"56b1db8ddb1ce01055a93324f3961908","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SDES9210.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"SDES9211","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES9211 - Integrated Studio: Culture and Identity","description":"

In this course you will investigate and critically analyse a range of design contexts considering cultural, social, behavioural, ethical, environmental and sustainability issues within a variety of local and global frameworks. Through a research-led and practice-based approach, you will analyse existing design responses with the intention of identifying and evaluating various perspectives to determine the validity of the design responses and associated processes. Furthering this research, you will synthesise and apply your knowledge to a prescribed design challenge in order to develop, articulate and justify a relevant design solution. Throughout the course you will reflect upon your own practice and identify, test and demonstrate your emerging values as a holistic and responsible global design practitioner.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"1b8b7e22dbc8a490eb6b147a3a96196a","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Precedent Studies","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

This assessment requires you to research and critically analyse a range of precedents to a series of design problems. Working in groups, you will select a design challenge from a prescribed list and then conduct group-initiated research and investigation into case studies that have adopted responses to similar problems. Your case studies should draw from diverse contexts in both local and global locations, addresses one or more Sustainable Development Goals (SDG), and include analysis of the stakeholders and design considerations utilised.  

\n

As a group, your report should include an analysis of these precedents and then synthesise the information as a range of potential responses to your selected design challenge. It should also include an individual reflection component on your own emerging values as a design practitioner. The report must include visual and written components and include a comprehensive reference list in APA style format 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9e7cb262dbc8a490eb6b147a3a9619b7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ba4cb262dbc8a490eb6b147a3a9619b6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1f8b7e22dbc8a490eb6b147a3a961970","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Studio Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

This assessment builds upon the knowledge gained in Assessment 1 and requires you to produce a range of diverse design solutions for a prescribed challenge and context. You will select this challenge from a prescribed list (the challenges will be similar and/or relate to those in Assessment 1).  

\n

Your final project should reflect a holistic approach that identifies all stakeholders, addresses at least one Sustainable Development Goals (SDG), and includes 2D, 3D and possibly 4D solutions to the challenge. It should also clearly demonstrate your own emerging values as a responsible design practitioner. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6f5c7262dbc8a490eb6b147a3a961970","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9e7cb262dbc8a490eb6b147a3a9619b7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2b8b7e22dbc8a490eb6b147a3a961978","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SDES9211.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

This course provides you with the opportunity to develop a major design project, which both engages with your studio specialisation studies and your understanding of integrated design and project management. The project should respond to an issue, dilemma or problem, from which a concept, brief and solution will be developed. You will have access to a variety of disciplines and are encouraged to develop multidisciplinary approaches.
