contentlets.keywords: design studies,integrated design,multidisciplinary design,design project
contentlets.description: This course provides you with the opportunity to develop a major design project, which both engages with your studio specialisation studies and your understanding of integrated design and project management. The project should respond to an issue, dilemma or problem, from which a concept, brief and solution will be developed. You will have access to a variety of disciplines and are encouraged to develop multidisciplinary approaches.
contentlets.title: Design Studio Project

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"SDES9213","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES9213 - Design Studio Project A","description":"

This course focuses on the development of a detailed and thoroughly researched design brief and presentation that will serve as a critical foundation for the design work undertaken for Design Studio Project B.  


This advanced level course will support you to apply design thinking, research and problem-framing skills, to the development and presentation of a detailed design brief in response to the complex issues and sustainability challenges facing contemporary society. You will work both independently and as part of multidisciplinary teams to undertake rigorous and systematic research into end-users, clients and stakeholders.


Through the knowledge and experience gained in the studio-specialisations you will explore materials, processes and supply chains to support your critical engagement with relevant theory, concepts and precedents, including responsible design practices. The course culminates in the presentation of a detailed, client-focused design brief and accompanying report that provides a critical and in-depth articulation of the design context, the methodologies and methods applied, and the criteria for guiding and evaluating the design work that will be undertaken in Design Studio Project B.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"2f5fb226dbc8a490eb6b147a3a961989","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Testing and Prototyping","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

This task is about developing and communicating your understanding of the people, places and ‘problems’ you are interested in designing for, and presenting a number of different design approaches that you can discuss with a hypothetical client and/or group of users or project stakeholders.   

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"235fb226dbc8a490eb6b147a3a96198c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2b5fb226dbc8a490eb6b147a3a96198b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bf5fb226dbc8a490eb6b147a3a96199f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Mapping the Problem Space, Critical Perspectives","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

This task is about developing and communicating your understanding of the people, places and ‘problems’ you are interested in designing for.

\n

In order to design an effective ‘solution’ it is essential to understand ‘the problem’ that you are wanting to address. This is usually not as simple as it might seem, and rather than just one problem, we often discover many different problems or challenges that need to be taken into account when we begin the design process. The many different problems considered as a whole constitute what we call the ‘problem space’. These problems are often rooted in complex human and ecological systems, so it is important to examine the social, cultural, philosophical, and political dimensions of the problem/opportunity you are designing for, in order to gain a fresher perspective - and make better informed assumptions about what it is we seeking to achieve.    

\n

The purpose of this task is to help you gain a better and more holistic understanding of the people, places and problems you are interested in designing for, by looking at these problems from several different perspectives. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"235fb226dbc8a490eb6b147a3a96198c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2f5fb226dbc8a490eb6b147a3a96198a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ef5fb226dbc8a490eb6b147a3a96198d","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SDES9213.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

This advanced level course will support you to apply design thinking, research and problem-framing skills, to the development and presentation of a detailed design brief in response to the complex issues and sustainability challenges facing contemporary society. You will work both independently and as part of multidisciplinary teams to undertake rigorous and systematic research into end-users, clients and stakeholders.

Through the knowledge and experience gained in the studio-specialisations you will explore materials, processes and supply chains to support your critical engagement with relevant theory, concepts and precedents, including responsible design practices. The course culminates in the presentation of a detailed, client-focused design brief and accompanying report that provides a critical and in-depth articulation of the design context, the methodologies and methods applied, and the criteria for guiding and evaluating the design work that will be undertaken in Design Studio Project B.

This course focuses on the development and presentation of a refined design proposal and body of work that builds on the research conducted in Design Studio Project 1. It provides you with the opportunity to complete and present a major design project and professional presentation.


This course will provide you with an understanding of design practice through the critical application of the theories, concepts and methods applied in the development and evaluation of design concepts. Using an iterative process, you will experiment with materials and the methods for prototyping, testing and evaluating designs that build on the knowledge and experience gained throughout the Master of Design program.


Throughout the course you will continue to work individually, and as part of multidisciplinary teams, to develop critical, rigorous and highly-resolved responses to the design brief prepared in Design Studio Project 1.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"24a31576db47e090be4672f5f39619fd","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Final Design Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

In the final phase of your design project you will engage in a self-directed schedule of work to produce your final design outcomes. Using effective resource and time management you must plan, organise and deliver your work demonstrating a high level of critical engagement, creative innovation and appropriate technical ability. 

You will demonstrate your ability to present your work, and enhance your capacity to engage in professional practice, through an assessment panel presentation and the submission of a 2000 word report. It is expected that you will refine, adapt and expand the draft report from assessment 1 for this final report. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"20a31576db47e090be4672f5f39619ff","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"20a35576db47e090be4672f5f3961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"24a31576db47e090be4672f5f39619fe","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"28a31576db47e090be4672f5f39619ff","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e8a35576db47e090be4672f5f3961908","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Critical Design Project Development","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Working independently, you are to refine and evaluate the design project idea/s developed in SDES9213 to establish a final design project proposal for production in Assessment 2.    

To do this you must undertake a critical reflection of your design project ideas from SDES9213 and identify specific aspects that require further research and development, which will be critical to the success of the project.  This will include expanding on and/or refining the contextual conditions of your design strategy, your theoretical and conceptual framework, material and production approach, and evaluation criteria.  

You will concentrate this body of work into a written report, which will form the first draft of your final design project report. You will create a short presentation that summarises your work and present this in the studio along with prototypes. You should include references to issues including sustainability and ethics, along with a production schedule for the next phase of your project work.

This course is designed to challenge the way in which you think about and create the spaces we inhabit everyday. The philosophy behind the approach to this studio is to extend the process of design as an acquired skill through serious play, and for you to explore, examine and demonstrate your conceptual understandings. This course will provide you with the opportunity to explore in both theoretical and practical terms the future of domestic life and domestic environments. You will explore the domestic environment and how we will live our domestic lives in the future. What the domestic environment will look like, what part technology will play and what impact our growing energy use will have on our environment and our lifestyles. You will collaborate to create studio outcomes that are informed by various disciplines to develop projects that are grounded in defensible concepts. This course will focus on developing creative strategies along with conventions used in design thinking, visualisation, prototyping, documentation and presentation. Building upon your foundations in theory and the practice of design, the course aims to develop your skills and understandings so that you can better integrate strategies employed in the design process, thereby enhancing the realisation of design outcomes within particular contexts.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"SDES9305","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES9305 - Participatory Design for Commercial Contexts","description":"

This course is designed to challenge the way you think about design and designing in a contemporary context. The philosophy behind the approach to this studio is to extend and explore in both theoretical and practical terms the ways in which models of participatory design can be used when designing in commercial contexts.


Participatory Design is also known as cooperative design, social design or co-design, and encompasses innovative design practices which actively involve all stakeholders to ensure the designed outcomes meets the clients needs, is fit for purpose and usable. This way of design is particularly valued in the development of commercial products and services.


Participatory Design for Commercial Contexts will challenge student notions of 'designing for' through encouraging experimentation, allowing for the development of a model of practice that is interdisciplinary, collaborative and critically focused on the ideas of 'designing with','live briefs' and social inclusion. You will be supported by relevant theory and will use an action learning approach to undertake a series of projects to develop your ability to identify commercial stakeholders, their needs and methods.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"4e518937db391c50eb6b147a3a96196f","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Co Design / Participatory Design : workshop planning

Students will plan a workshop or co design experience for stakeholders in relation to the project they have identified.


Verbal and peer feedback in class.

Formal written feedback from facilitator

","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"61518937db391c50eb6b147a3a961951","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Design Research exercise : understanding stakeholders. 

Students will identify an opportunity and its audience of stakeholders.  They will use design research tools to gain an understanding of the needs, wants and desires of these stakeholders in relation to the opportunity.


Verbal and peer feedback in class.

Formal written feedback from facilitator

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"35518937db391c50eb6b147a3a961969","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a9518937db391c50eb6b147a3a961955","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Designed Outcome: Students will design a product, service, exprience or product service system for their identified stakeholders leveraging the work they have done in tasks 1 and 2.


Verbal and peer feedback in class.

Formal written feedback from facilitator

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"SDES9311","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES9311 - Interaction Design Foundations","description":"

This course provides an introduction to the field of interaction design, developing technical, theoretical and creative skills in interactive systems – with a focus on designing and producing tangible and embodied interactions (i.e. objects and wearables). Human-centred design methods are used to research real-world problems, situations and opportunities for the implementation of innovative interactive designs.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"4661293bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961948","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Interactive media player prototype","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

For this task you will work in teams of 3-4 and use off-the-shelf sensing technologies (e.g. Arduino) and software prototyping tools (e.g. Max) to explore and document the variety of ways in which interfaces can be used for interacting with multimedia content. This task has been designed to help you develop your understanding of user input, feature extraction and mapping methods for using interfaces to control multimedia content.

Your team will be required to design, build and test an interface for navigating and controlling a collection of recorded sound and/or video content. The system you build needs to demonstrate an exploration of ways to recognise and translate user interactions that involve some element of time and/or gesture (e.g. hold, tap, double tap, shake, wobble etc).

This task will be presented as part of a public exhibition event, where you will be expected to run user studies (with methods described in class) for analysis and further prototype development in the course. Presentations will be coordinated by your lecturer before the event opens to the public with each group allowed 10 minutes to present.

The individual component of this task requires you to document your own contribution to the group work, and reflect on key learnings you identified during the exhibition. This can be captured through sketches and documentation photos, and should describe the user testing/evaluation methods you have applied to the task. Report word count should not exceed 1000 words.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0a61293bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"4661293bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961935","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"4a61293bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961944","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3561293bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961915","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Interactive design evaluation and development","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

Using the lessons you learned in your user study (Assessment 1), you will evaluate feedback from your prototype design (described in a written report; 1500 words) and develop this into an interactive product or system (presented in class; 5 mins) that addresses the perceived strengths and/or weaknesses of your group prototype.

By applying the concepts and methods you have learned in the course, explore and expand upon what you observed in the group exhibition, using user testing and feedback to support your position. Based on your understanding from this data, design and propose a new iteration of your prototype. This does not need to a development of the original prototype in its entirety, rather, you can focus on a single design element or function of the group work.

Present your new iteration using sketches and relevant visual references to evidence your design process. It is not a requirement to develop a functional prototype (as is the case in Task 1), however you should experiment with materials as part of your process, to explore their relationship with tangible and embodied human interactions.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"SDES9312","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES9312 - Interaction Design: Human-Centred Design Methods","description":"

This course provides an introduction to user-research, concept development and visual communication methods used in the development and evaluation of websites and mobile apps, along with an introduction to techniques for prototyping screen-based designs for web and mobile interactions.


You will research a real world situation, develop insights into users, the activities they are engaging in, and the context-of-use, to identify themes, issues and opportunities for interactive designs.


The course culminates in the presentation of an original design proposal and prototype interactive website or mobile app, developed using the insights developed from your user-research, and realised using physical and digital prototyping techniques that will be introduced as part of this studio.


 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"825f74ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96196a","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"hat is User Experience?","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

For this task you will undertake academic research and write a report introducing the field of user experience (UX). This report should communicate a sense of what the field is; why it matters; the different roles and kinds of work undertaken in UX; and what it takes to succeed as a UX professional.

Include in your report a statement outlining your personal vision for how you see UX as relevant to the kind of work you want to be doing after graduation. Reflect on your own unique set of work-and-life-experiences and consider how these could be useful for working in UX, as well as the new UX-related skills and sensitivities you will need to develop, taking into account the many aspects of UX work you have identified through your research.

This is an individual task that you complete on your own. Word count (1000 words) excludes captions, footnotes and bibliography section.

Please refer to the detailed assessment task brief (available on Moodle in Week 1) for detailed requirements, deliverables and suggested document structure.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3d5f74ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961960","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b55f74ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961966","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"215f74ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961910","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Observations and Vision","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

This task has a groupwork and individual component. For part A, in groups of 4-5 you will conduct interviews to reflect on the end-user experience with an interactive product or service. Based on these interviews, develop an Affinity Map, storyboards and scenarios to identify themes and requirements into user needs. Use these observations to present an interactive design concept, the activity you are designing for, and the context in which these activities take place.

For part B, you will submit a 1500 word journal which tracks your personal development and understanding of human-centred design over the first 7 weeks of the course. This journal should identify on your own role in realising Assessment 2, and reflect on the insights you have taken from the groupwork component of this assessment. Synthesise this personal experience with the knowledge you have gained through methods discussed in class, using correct referencing where appropriate.

Please refer to the detailed assessment task brief (available on Moodle in Week 1) for detailed requirements, deliverables and suggested document structure.

Weighting: Groupwork (part A) 60%, Individual (part B) 40%.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3d5f74ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961960","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"795f74ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961963","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b55f74ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961966","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"695f74ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961914","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Design Prototype","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Building on the ‘consolidated vision’ you developed with your group for Assessment 2, you will individually construct a prototype of your design concept. You will then evaluate this prototype with a potential user and evaluate the feedback to inform the your final design.

Present your design in class, documenting your process and reflecting on the challenges and insights you encountered. Frame this discussion around the user experience and problem space you have been designing for.

Please refer to the detailed assessment task brief (available on Moodle in Week 1) for detailed requirements, deliverables and suggested document structure.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"SDES9315","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES9315 - Tangible Interfaces and Interactive Displays","description":"

Interactive exhibits in museums, visitor centres and gallery settings, enable visitors to engage with complex materials, revealing hidden connections and providing a shared focus for active exploration and conversation. In this studio, you will research, design and produce an interactive exhibit for a museum or visitor-centre, and explore approaches to interfacing with multimedia content (i.e. images, audio recordings, videos) that go beyond conventional keyboard, mouse and touch screen interactions to explore the possibilities of more tangible and physically dynamic ways of interacting and exploring multimedia materials through a range of sensing technologies from RFID tags, to gestural interactions and other touch and movement sensing technologies.


Building on skills and knowledge developed in Interaction Design: Foundations for Human Computer Interaction, you will advance your skills in the design, production and evaluation of interactive exhibits, with a focus on ergonomics, interaction aesthetics, electronics and the manipulation of audio-visual materials. You will develop familiarity with theories and principals of interface design, signal-mapping, interaction aesthetics and exhibition design and apply this to the development of a functioning prototype exhibit based on research into emerging real-world applications for interactive displays and interpretive systems in the field of exhibition design.


Lectures, case studies and tutorial presentations will introduce you to the principals of interface design, signal-mapping, and interaction aesthetics, and hands-on technical workshops will will enable you to develop your skills integrating off-the-shelf components and systems with software tools for navigating immersive visualisations.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"5ec430f3dbb51c50eb6b147a3a96195f","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Major Project: Interactive Information Visualisation","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

A prototype interactive museum exhibit, using a tangible or embodied interface to navigate audio-visual multimedia content.

A detailed briefing for these tasks will be provided at the start of the course.


Grades and written feedback will be published online via Review. Additional feedback will be provided during individual consultations. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"06c430f3dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961959","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"42c430f3dbb51c50eb6b147a3a96195c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c6c430f3dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961956","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"02c430f3dbb51c50eb6b147a3a96194d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Part 1. A 2500 word academic research paper, providing a critical evaluation of theoretical principals and precedents in the area of tangible and/or 'embodied' interfaces for multimedia interactive exhibits.

 

Part 2. Final Project Documentation and Evaluation Report.

 

A detailed briefing for these tasks will be provided at the start of the course.

 


Grades and written feedback will be published online via Review. Additional feedback will be provided during individual consultations. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c6c430f3dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961956","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bdc430f3dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961943","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Proposal and Technical Demonstration","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Part 1. Individual Task - Develop and present your proposoal for an interactive exhibit, articulating the design requirements for materials/stories being exhibited, the interface concepts you explored, and design precedents that have informed your interface and interaction concept.

 Part 2. Individual Task - Technical Demonstration of a prototype interactive exhibit, combining sensing components with software development to access and then map sensor data to an interactive display.

A detailed briefing for these tasks will be provided at the start of the course.


Grades and written feedback will be published online via Review. Additional feedback will be provided during individual consultations.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES9316 - Wearable and Bio-Sensing Interactions","description":"

This course focuses on the design, development and evaluation of wearable and biometric (body-sensing) interactions for artistic, wellness, rehabilitation, or educational applications. Students extend their knowledge of interaction design and apply this to the development of a prototype design that analyses and responds intelligently to data collected via analogue and digital biosensors. 


The course provides students with an introduction to the theory and practice of wearable and health related digital technology. The past five years have seen tremendous growth in the area of wearable and biometric technologies, and this growth is set to continue. This course provides students with an introduction to design and engineering issues and approaches for addressing the functional and aesthetic requirements these new forms of interactions present.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c94c38f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619bc","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Projects – Investigative Development","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Drawing on key theories, issues and frameworks from the field of human- computer interaction and media arts, apply these in a coherent way to the evaluation of body-focussed interactive designs and design-problems to develop and refine an interactive product, service or environment through an iterative process of research, development, testing and evaluation of a rough prototype.

Research Presentation (6min) including testing and critical evaluation of a rough prototype - with another student.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c94c38f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619a9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"304c38f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961980","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Product – Realisation and Prototyping","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

For this task you will integrate and refine the design concepts you developed in Task 2, into final iteration of your wearable or body-focussed interaction. The final working design will be presented in class, and accompanied by a 5min video documentation comprising: 3min outline of the design concept, research questions and development process, and critical evaluation of the final design in relation to your initial aims and research questions and 2min project video documentary.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"094c38f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ac","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"784c38f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961984","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Ideas - Research and Conceptualisation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Describe key theories, issues and frameworks from the field of human-computer interaction and media arts, and apply these in a coherent way to the evaluation of body-focussed interactive designs and design-problems.

Write a 1000-word academic research paper, summarising and reflecting on key historic precedents, directions, and critical debates relevant to the proposed approach and context you wish to design for. (submit paper in Moodle).

Prepare a 6min presentation of research and concept paper to present in class with visual aids and concept sketches. Refer to detailed design brief online via Moodle.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8d4c38f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619a6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f44c38f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a96197b","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SDES9316.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Students extend their knowledge of interaction design and apply this to the development of a prototype design that analyses and responds intelligently to data collected via analogue and digital biosensors. 

The course provides students with an introduction to the theory and practice of wearable and health related digital technology. The past five years have seen tremendous growth in the area of wearable and biometric technologies, and this growth is set to continue. This course provides students with an introduction to design and engineering issues and approaches for addressing the functional and aesthetic requirements these new forms of interactions present.

The goal of this practical studio course is to develop your understanding of 3D computer visualisation and Visual Effects (VFX). The focus is to give you live hands-on experience of key technologies and methodological thinking. Workshops will include: Project mapping, 3D visualisation masterclasses, VFX workflow and arts-led 3D computer modelling. During the course you will be introduced to a series of briefs focused on emergent research themes in the field; including, 3D biomedical visualisation, motion capture and 3D arts-led computer visualisation

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a2b1fcbbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961935","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research and previsualisation","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Access to scientific data is becoming more widespread with a variety of scientific approaches to visualising molecular, anatomical and architectural structures. However, this type of visualisation can often be driven by scientific or purely by a didactic agenda. The core of this brief is to explore alternative arts-led visual aesthetics of biomedical data or architectural spaces. Using the 3D CGI toolkit you are tasked with developing alternative and experimental modes of visualisation to communicate a concept or process. Students will choose from one of two design briefs outlined in week 1. In this task you will plan the construction of a 3D CGI model. Individually you will compile a visual journal (through a online blog) that documents the process involved in developing your 3D CGI work. The purpose of this assignment is to become familiar with the process of researching and previsualising 3D CGI. The starting point should be some form of scan data or data source related to either brief. How you interpret and construct the visual aesthetic should be informed by your theoretical and contextual research.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6ab1fcbbdb751c50eb6b147a3a96192e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1eb1fcbbdb751c50eb6b147a3a96190c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Realisation: 3D CGI model","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

As a continuation of your assessment in Task 1, Task 2 is based on the completion and realisation of your 3D CGI model. The intention is for you to draw on your background research and any tests carried out during the previsualisation stage. Your model should be fully complete with a UV map, texture, digital lighting and rendering. All students must individually submit their digital 3D outputs of their 3D CGI model to the Coursework Folder for SDES9320 on Moodle. Students are also required to clearly connect their visual aesthetic to their theoretical and contextual research. Submission details on UNSW Course Moodle pages under Assignments.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"66b1fcbbdb751c50eb6b147a3a96191f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"56b1fcbbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961911","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Presentation and reflection","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

The purpose of task 3 is for you to orally communicate the outcome and your background research in task 1 and 2. This 10 minute oral presentation should include personal reflections with experiments and techniques discussed. Students should also communicate how they might improve their individual outcome and the lessons learned for any future 3D visualisation project(s). All students should also prepare presentation slides to support their oral presentation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a6b1fcbbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961931","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9eb1fcbbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961915","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SDES9320.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"SDES9321","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES9321 - 3D Digital Aesthetics","description":"

 



This course offers an in-depth exploration of 3D/Visual Effects [VFX] as a mode of critical inquiry an early stage of the student’s academic program. Students will be introduced to the genre of 3D and VFX in the context of digital aesthetics, narrative structures and contemporary research practices. Through practical experiments, students will interrogate our unprecedented ability to digitally replicate and represent our physical world through 3D imaging and digital visualisation. Students will explore the role of technology in enabling a new way of seeing, thinking and generating meaning. They will examine aesthetic approaches to screen-based digital narrative structures, ranging from documentary animation to medical visualisation as examples of this process.


 By the end of this course, students will gain a practical understanding of 3D/VFX as a mode of critical enquiry through experimentations with linear and non-linear narrative projects that are underpinned by a theoretical framework. Students will gain critical skills that enable them to interrogate their practice in an academic context.


 The course will consist of 3-hour weekly seminars combined with a series of practical tasks including the development of traditional and experimental digital narratives. Students will be engaged in an immersive learning environment including extended laboratory access, regular group seminars and an online learning community.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"1fb1fcbbdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619d5","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Screen Narrative Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

This assessment tasks asks students to analyse a screen-based narrative. Students will choose from one of the three thematic briefs provided on the course Moodle and select one of the case studies provided to analyse. Through a text-based reflection and oral presentation students are asked to break down one example into its component parts and critically analyse the material. 5 minute oral presentation in class.

400 word reflection submitted via Moodle before class.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"43b1fcbbdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619a7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"72b1fcbbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961988","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Students are asked to develop a proposal for a screen based outcome to be developed for Assessment 3. Responding to one of the thematic briefs provided, the proposal will relate a theoretical approach based upon concepts students have encountered in the course. The proposal will communicate the narrative structure, aesthetic and technical approach to be undertaken and will include a visual script, mood boards, storyboard and previsualisation.

5-10 minute oral presentation in class.
1000 word proposal including visual materials submitted via Moodle before class.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d3b1fcbbdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619cf","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8bb1fcbbdb751c50eb6b147a3a96198c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Digital Aesthetics - Individual project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

As planned in assessment 2, students will produce an animatic, drawing upon concepts and processes encountered throughout the course. The focus of the assessment is upon identification and implementation of narrative and aesthetic concepts relating to 3D and visual effects based practices and processes they have encountered in the course, rather than the scale, complexity or refinement of the visual outcome. A short reflection will also be submitted summarising the work undertaken and identifying where and how the eventual outcome may have shifted from the original proposal.

500 word reflection submitted via Moodle before class.

Video file submitted in class for screening.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES9350 - Urban Intervention: People Places and Cultural Contexts","description":"

This interdisciplinary studio course supports you in undertaking critical investigations into contemporary urban space and the intersections of public and private space.  You will work collaboratively in developing design for urban Interventions that allow rethinking the nature of urban public space and architecture in cities.


Students are encouraged to bring their developing modes of practice, and spatial intelligence to the projects and expand their practice in response to the interaction, intervention and documentation of city spaces. This course will support students from a variety of backgrounds, including design, art, sculpture, sociology and built environment.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"905f34ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96194c","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Presentation: An Urban Intervention","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Working in groups of three (or exceptionally two) you will develop one of the projects presented in Assignment 2, advancing the design exploration and providing detailed documentation of the outcome. 

Each member of the group will take responsibility for one aspect of the design development. This personal contribution will be assessed independently. However, it is essential that individual elements cohere into a whole as the project will also be assessed as a single group work.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"185f34ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961933","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"905f34ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961939","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"dc5f34ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96193b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"045f34ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961927","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Walking the Walk or Making Connections: An Investigation and analysis of urban space","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

This project is designed to encourage the development of imagination, creativity and critical thinking through observation and the acquisition of practical skills involved in giving form to ideas. Through the process of analysing an urban site, you will develop understandings of design concepts and principles, language, materials, techniques and processes by which they are expressed. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"545f34ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961936","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d85f34ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961930","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"dc5f34ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96193b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"805f34ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96191e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Interim Presentation: An Urban Intervention","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

You will develop a pitch for a new "experience" on the selected site, with a view to convincing a consortium led by the City of Sydney to realise your proposal. In addition to an A1 poster illustrating your proposal, you will have three minutes to "pitch" it to the consortium.

At the end of the project, the top pitches will go through to the next round, where they will be developed in Assignment 3.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"185f34ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961933","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"dc5f34ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96193b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c85f34ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961922","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SDES9350.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.keywords: design studies,urban,space,landscape architecture,urban design
contentlets.description:
This interdisciplinary studio course supports you in undertaking critical investigations into contemporary urban space and the intersections of public and private space.  You will work collaboratively in developing design for urban Interventions that allow rethinking the nature of urban public space and architecture in cities.

Students are encouraged to bring their developing modes of practice, and spatial intelligence to the projects and expand their practice in response to the interaction, intervention and documentation of city spaces. This course will support students from a variety of backgrounds, including design, art, sculpture, sociology and built environment.
contentlets.title: Urban Intervention: People Places and Cultural Contexts

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"SDES9352","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES9352 - Imperatives for a Sustainable Future","description":"

Imperatives for a Sustainable Future provides you with a critical understanding of the theoretical and practical implications of design as a professional activity and the impacts it can have on a local, regional and global scale. It aims to develop an understanding of how to deal with complexity and wicked problems using a design thinking framework informed by an understanding of the four pillars of sustainability. You will use foresight tools for developing sustainable strategies as well as methods for measuring and monitoring successful implementation.


Key themes will include the four pillars of sustainability, futurist philosophies, wicked problems, sticky solutions, complexity, interdependency, products, services and systems, localism, manufacturing methods, responsibility in leadership and cross disciplinary collaboration. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c69178bbdb751c50eb6b147a3a96199b","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Ethics, Design and Objects","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Select 1 object from the 6 you selected for the Nature-culture spectrum activity in Week 2.

Write a 100 word critical reflection on how your object relates to the ethics of design. What, if any, ethical issues arise from your object?

To begin, describe this item: Weight, Size, Purpose, Functionality, Materials, Use, Origin, Where/how you obtained it. If you use it, how do you use it? What it means to you i.e. why you value it?

The analysis of ethical issues in the designed artefact, and raised by the artefact itself, should be provided in as much detail as possible. In other words: in what ways does the designed artefact contribute to a better or worse world (however you define these terms). In conclusion, how ethical in your opinion is the designed artefact? What changes if any would you recommend to make the object more 'ethical'?

Submit your report as a pdf, 11 point font, single column, A4 portrait orientation, with no coloured text or coloured backgrounds. Include image(s) of your object. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"359178bbdb751c50eb6b147a3a96198f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"bd9178bbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961994","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"259178bbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961970","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Life Cycle Analysis","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Form a group of 3. You will carry out a Life Cycle Analysis (LCA) of a commonly available designed object, and will present your analysis as a digital poster for classroom display. Then, using your projected poster, present a 10-minute visual and verbal presentation on the object and your LCA of it, including a discussion of the implications of its engagement with sustainable design.

The assignment aims for you to analyse first-hand existing design and develop your own proposals to re-design existing designs, to reduce the environmental impacts of your chosen designed object. 

The focus of the assignment is not about learning LCA software, or the exact numbers of your LCA in your poster or presentation. Instead the aim is to develop your skills in critiquing existing design, and to reflect on your understanding of how LCA and the principle of LCA software may be used to reduce the environmental impacts of your design.

Steps to follow to do this assignment: 

- Select a designed object or artifact

- Provide a brief explanation of the artifact and its purpose, including an image.

- Describe in as much detail as possible the life cycle of the artifact from design through production, distribution, use and disposal.

- Note the environmental impacts of this life cycle.

- Propose alternatives to reduce the environmental impacts.

- Present your findings as a self-explanatory poster. This means that the poster should explain itself. Think of it sitting in the staff room of your work place, where you are not there to explain to people what it means, but that you want the poster to entice and intrigue them. Ask your group partners: "Do you think that the poster would be intuitive if it was displayed without our presentation?"

- Give a 10 minute group presentation in class to accompany your poster, with 2-3 minutes of questions and discussion with your class.

- Reference sources of information you have used for this project – these generally go at the bottom of the poster in small font, like footnotes in an essay.

- File should be a high resolution jpg or pdf.

- You may use any kind of software to create your poster (e.g. Photoshop, InDesign, Illustrator).

- Only 1 person in each group should upload their poster file.

- Submit an electronic copy via Moodle with a cover sheet as a separate document signed by all participants indicating equal participation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"bd9178bbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961994","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f99178bbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961997","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6d9178bbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961974","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Design in Context: Ecology, Economics and Politics","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

In this task you will undertake a critical case study of two related products/services/product service systems that purport to be sustainable in some way. Critically analyse your two selections. Are they sustainable? Why? According to what criteria? Are the claims made by the designer/manufacturer/producer honest or accurate or correct? Compare and contrast them – what does their comparison reveal about their respective approaches to sustainable design? Are they an improvement on what has come before? Are there better alternatives? What contexts are relevant to their sustainability: ecology and/or economics and/or politics? Discuss and expand.

To undertake this case study you will make observations, and source information in order to evaluate the ecological, economic and/or political dimensions of your two selections. You will then explore the potential for improving the environmental impact of your selection, including a proposed strategic design intervention that will likely result in less unsustain-able practices. To develop this potential what would you do differently? You will also design a flowchart/diagram that illustrates your proposed strategic design intervention. Both the design decisions developed in your essay and the position taken in your intervention should reference theories and practices studied in the course.

Optional:

You may make do your critical case study on graphic design, visual communication, illustration and related fields if you like. Provided you discuss your intended approach with your tutor and they approve it. Reason being is that some such design fields may prefer to use the assignment to better their understanding of these fields, rather than the design of a product, service, or product service system.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES9464 - Cultural Textiles: Field Trips","description":"

Cultural Textiles: Field Trip is a short-term overseas study course to study textiles in a specific Asian country. The course focuses on artisan produced textiles, giving students the opportunity to understand the cultural, social and environmental issues impacting on production, with the potential of future engagement via major projects, research studies or to engage locally in design projects. The countries where Cultural Textiles: Field Trip course may be conducted are India, Indonesia, Thailand, Laos and Japan. 


The program allows students to benefit from lectures by regional experts; research textiles in museums; see demonstrations of textiles being made; participate in workshops conducted in artisan or community centres; meet designers and artisans; and learn about the issues impacting on this field of contemporary design.


The Cultural Textiles course will focus the how, where, what and the nature of production by artisan, family, village and community groups. Of particular interest is how textile traditions are maintained by these groups, how organizations work to maintain these traditions and how textiles traditions impact on contemporary designs. The Cultural Textiles course allows students to study, research and experience specific textile techniques giving them insights into how to design for, collaborate with, commission or engage with these artisan groups in the future. The various textiles techniques covered by the course depends on the location but will include a selection from block or ajarkh printing; specific embroidery techniques; resist patterning techniques eg bandani, shibori or ikat; or interlacing techniques such as weaving, basketry, ply splitting or twinning. 


Introductory seminar(s) are held at the Faculty of Art & Design prior to departure. Assessment tasks comprise a detailed travel journal; a range of textile design croquis (ideas) and a major research essay. Submission of projects will be 3 to 4 weeks after the end of the field trip component of the course. 


Note: This course is suited to PG (coursework) students in their second, third or final semester of their course who have elected to study a Faculty of Art & Design textiles course; students are responsible for their own travel arrangements and associated costs during the field trip eg accommodation, workshop fees, internal travel; an additional up-front fee is required by the Faculty of Art & Design to cover the specific cost of delivering the field trip component of the course overseas. Estimates of these costs will be available once the specific field trip location has been announced. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"791e1dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b8","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Cultural Textiles documentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

This task is to document each day of the fieldwork course and your experience of being overseas through a journal, or in specifically approved cases, a video. 

Work in your journal in the way that suits you - this can include sketches, drawing, diagrams, images, writings, found objects, photos, brochures etc.

Your journal or video should document your field trip experience, places visited, demonstrations, presentation on artisan textiles, workshops given as part of the course and the issues impacting on the handloom sector. It should include observations of culture, life, environment, artisan objects, textiles, patterns, structures and information gathered from presentations, workshops, visits etc. It should also include design or art ideas to represent your experiences.Your journal or video should provide comprehensive documentation of your experience during the Cultural Textiles course and be a substantial record of Cultural Textiles fieldwork course. 

Your journal is to include four short reports on selected social enterprise organisations or designers or artisan communities visited during the fieldwork component of the course. You will need to include these four reports in your journal; each report should be at least 200 words and include appropriate referencing and full acknowledgement of all quotes, images and text. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"291e1dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961993","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"7d1e1dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f11e1dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619af","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"291e1dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961985","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"A range of textile design croquis / ideas","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

Develop a range of art or design ideas for contemporary textiles that could be made by a selected artisan or community group visited during the Cultural Textiles fieldwork course. 

Art ideas should illustrate ideas for an exhibition or project; this could be an exhibition of your work but include artwork made by the artisan group; or it could be a collaborative project with the artisan group with artwork jointly made by the artisan group and you. 

A design range comprises designs for textiles. As croquis, they do not need to show a repeat; these should show colours appropriate for your design with infomarion on how they will be made eg if block printed in natural designs then use appropriate colours. These can be textile or on paper (collaged, printed or painted).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"311e1dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"7d1e1dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"611e1dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96198a","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SDES9464.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"SDES9746","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES9746 - Textiles - Contemporary Studio","description":"

This course introduces contemporary textile practice in art and design applications for students involved in creative work for the first time. It introduces the context for designing and making; the narrative role textiles play in reflecting and documenting contemporary society; and the social, sustainable, re-use and environmental issues associated with this industry.


The course introduces textile techniques and processes; material properties and characteristics of fibres, fabrics and associated materials; current textile design issues and new technologies; the technical aspect of designing for a 2D surface and a 3D constructed textile; and the application of textiles across the design spectrum. It covers a number of techniques for surface design, printing, colouring and constructing cloth, giving students the knowledge and skills necessary to undertake contemporary textile design projects for various applications. 


This is a studio-based course, where practical projects are informed by integrating research, concepts and experimentation, and designs are realised in different studio based, hand and digital technologies and processes.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"87dff833db391c50eb6b147a3a9619cb","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Subversive Botanics","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Summary:

'Subversive Botanics' is a textile design project to produce a range of five textile designs utilizing a variety of mark making techniques. 'Subversive Botanics' is a two-dimensional surface-patterning project inspired by botanical references, and includes an element of subversion (danger, menace, jeopardy, surprise etc) to illustrate a unique concept.

Submission details:

Lesson 3: Submit documentation of concept board and draft statement to Moodle: 1 pdf document with file naming convention: SDES9746taskConcept_ studentname_studentnumber

Lesson 6: Submit documentation of all assessable work items 2 (10 best pages), 3 & 4 to Moodle compiled into 1 pdf document with file naming convention: SDES9746task1_studentname_studentnumber Max file size 200MB.

How will students receive feedback on this task:

Group and peer studio discussions, individual studio consultation, written and verbal feedback. Feedback will be delivered in a timely manner (no more than two weeks from the date of submission), be succinct and clear with personalized comments for each student.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"47dff833db391c50eb6b147a3a9619a6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"4fdff833db391c50eb6b147a3a9619c4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bedff833db391c50eb6b147a3a96198b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Resonate: a 2D/3D textile installation project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

Summary:

Design a textile installation referencing lace. Your experience of the Lace Study Centre** will assist in understanding what a 2D or 3D installation can be. Your client for the installation is an organisation, institution or business involved in environmental, culturally or socially sensitive work; an organisation responsible for a public space; or a medical or education institution. Your project is to be incorporated and integrated into your client’s interior space / environment in a way that your design creates a dialogue with your client’s work / practice in a beneficial or educational way. Your design should influence the viewer in some way: create a particular atmosphere, convey a particular message or express a concern for the future.

Submission details:

Part 2A Return Brief: weighting 15% Submit online via Moodle. One pdf file using the file naming convention: SDES9746Task2A_StudentName_StudentNumber

Part 2B Final Project: weighting 45% will be presented in class for feedback and discussion the lesson before final submission. Digital documentation of all assessable materials to be submitted via Moodle as one Pdf using naming convention: SDES9746task2B_StudentName_StudentNumber

How will students receive feedback on this task:

Group and peer studio discussions, individual studio consultation, written and verbal feedback. Feedback will be delivered in a timely manner (no more than two weeks from the date of submission), be succinct and clear with personalized comments for each student.

** The Lace Study Centre is at the Powerhouse Museum, Ultimo, Sydney. https://www.powerhousemuseum.com/lacestudycentre/ The centre is open 10.30am to 1.30pm weekdays and Saturday. Ring 9217 0222 for bookings or email edserv@phm.gov.au

This course focuses on the skills and processes used in the design and fabrication of contemporary furniture and lighting. You will be given the opportunity to select either furniture or lighting as the major driver for your skills development. The furniture design introduction will cover areas from forest to furniture sourcing and fabrication, solid timber, veneers, laminations, turning, and jointing techniques. The lighting design introduction will cover various contemporary light sources including Light Emitting Diodes (LEDS), and Plasma Lamps. Demonstrations will include discussion of lamp spectra, other lamp characteristics and how they contribute to a space. Attention will be given to the design and development of a sustainable practice in design by developing practical projects informed by integrating research, concepts and experimentation.

The furniture design introduction will cover areas from forest to furniture sourcing and fabrication, solid timber, veneers, laminations, turning, and jointing techniques. The lighting design introduction will cover various contemporary light sources including Light Emitting Diodes (LEDS), and Plasma Lamps. Demonstrations will include discussion of lamp spectra, other lamp characteristics and how they contribute to a space. Attention will be given to the design and development of a sustainable practice in design by developing practical projects informed by integrating research, concepts and experimentation.

This course introduces contemporary jewellery practice for art and design applications for students involved in creative work for the first time. It presents the context for designing and making, introducing students to the practical and theoretical concerns of contemporary jewellery and object design through a study of current issues techniques and materials.


Through experimentation with materials and jewellery processes students will be asked to realise works which are wearable jewellery objects. The studio activity will examine a variety of materials with a focus on the technology of metal and its translation through heat into three-dimensional forms. The techniques of soldering, casting and fabrication will be explored using non-ferrous metals to translate drawn designs into finished objects, giving students the knowledge and skills necessary to undertake contemporary jewellery design projects for various applications. 


This is a studio-based course, where practical projects are informed by the integration of research, concepts and material experiments to be  realised in finished jewellery works. These contemporary jewels are made using hand  processes and in some cases a combination of these processes with industrial processes and new technologies.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"b6110137db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b8","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"This Charmed Object","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

To create a series of three jewellery objects which considers the theme of the charm. The three wearable pieces MUST employ the key technical processes introduced in the studio.

In this assessment task, you are required to research and investigate the notion of the charm to create a series of pieces which work together as a group or work individually as units. The resulting work should take the form of a small wearable charm, object, amulet or talisman. The narrative could be based on contemporary or traditional life, fiction and or non-fiction.

You will be required to demonstrate proficiency in each of the five key processes through the production of three completed jewellery objects. The works should primarily consider metal in its production. Please consult your lecturer if you would like to introduce a different material to the project. In addition, the works need to explore at least two different methods of attachment to the body. All aspects of the work need to be handmade.

Key Technical Processes:

- Saw piercing

- Soldering

- Casting using lost wax processes

- Cold joining

- Surface treatment

Submission details:

Works to be set up beginning of class time in Week 5. These include: 

1. Three Finished Jewellery Objects and Process Journal. The process journal should document your experimentation with the five technical processes learned in class along with the development of the three jewellery objects.

2. Photograph/s of your three jewellery objects to be uploaded to Moodle by 7pm on the day of class.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6e110137db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"aa110137db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e2110137db391c50eb6b147a3a9619ac","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1e110137db391c50eb6b147a3a961991","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"This Charmed Life","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

As designers, we are frequently called upon to solve some of life’s daily problems with practical solutions to make life easier. The approach taken to small and large issues in life by makers of adornments throughout history is frequently more esoteric than purely utilitarian, addressing notions of belief, ritual, luck and the power invested in the (wearable) object.

Kevin Murray quotes:

Luck is a useful commodity for social relations. It’s the things we can’t control that define our common humanity. Without them, we’d have no stories to share. Everything would run like clockwork. The true power of objects such as charms, amulets and talismans is not based in any supernatural forces. They enable us to share what are otherwise private hopes and fears. To give someone a charm is a social contract. When you receive it, you invite the giver to inquire later about your fortune. ‘So, did it work? Was it lucky for you?’

K. Murray, Why? Traditions Contemporary Jewellery in the South, 2012, http://www.joyaviva.net/about/why/ (accessed 30 October 2018).

This project requires you to design and make a contemporary, wearable charm, amulet or talisman for your life or the life of someone you know. The design of your piece should be innovative and reflect its concept or intended function. It is to be made using metal in combination with other materials and utilise at least three of the five key technical processes introduced in this course.

Your finished work/s may require a ritual to be performed in order for it to be ‘activated’ – this should be clearly demonstrated or documented as part of your final presentation.

Documentation of the design process and final jewellery outcomes needs to be uploaded to the Jewel Blog via Moodle by 7pm of the assessment due date.

Submission details:

Works to be submitted and set up in the jewellery teaching room at the beginning of class time. These include:

1. A finished work or series of works,

2. Supporting documentation including photographs of the final outcome/s and reflection statement on Moodle.

contentlets.keywords: design studies,art jewellery,contemporary jewellery,jewellery design
contentlets.description:
This course introduces contemporary jewellery practice for art and design applications for students involved in creative work for the first time. It presents the context for designing and making, introducing students to the practical and theoretical concerns of contemporary jewellery and object design through a study of current issues techniques and materials.

Through experimentation with materials and jewellery processes students will be asked to realise works which are wearable jewellery objects. The studio activity will examine a variety of materials with a focus on the technology of metal and its translation through heat into three-dimensional forms. The techniques of soldering, casting and fabrication will be explored using non-ferrous metals to translate drawn designs into finished objects, giving students the knowledge and skills necessary to undertake contemporary jewellery design projects for various applications. 

This is a studio-based course, where practical projects are informed by the integration of research, concepts and material experiments to be  realised in finished jewellery works. These contemporary jewels are made using hand  processes and in some cases a combination of these processes with industrial processes and new technologies.
contentlets.title: Jewellery Studio

This course enables postgraduate students to undertake an approved 'Special Project' as part of their academic program. SDES 9758 'Special Project' courses are available as electives to postgraduate (coursework) students.


A 'Special Project' involves specific, one off opportunities that may arise, which will benefit an individual student or groups of students, or participation in scheduled industry, professional community or other design related activities. This includes supervised international experiences (such as a study tour; exhibition participation or attendance; specific workshops or courses with leading designers etc) or special projects such as professional practice in the context of specific events (eg National or International Biennales, Design conferences, festivals, events or competitions etc) or the opportunity to undertake an individual project in conjunction with an academic within the University, for example. Course content, focus and outcomes of specific projects may be individually negotiated or may be established and repeated periodically, depending on the nature of the 'Special Project' and the interest and availability of groups of students at a particular time.


A generic Course Outline for SDES 9758 is available from the UNSW Online Handbook. Specific course outlines will be written and distributed for each 'Special Project' offered. These will detail the academic content, objectives, assessment criteria, modes of teaching and learning, expectations and requirements of student participation appropriate for the event or proposal.
