","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"SDES9760","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES9760 - Introduction to Graphics Media","description":"

This course explores the principles of visual communication through a range of brand design projects. By observing the branded identities of people, places, and services as well as products and organisations, you will develop and present designed identities for print, screen, and outdoor application. Reflection on the contextual factors that impact the interpretation and use of the identity will inform its development.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"009aa133dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619e2","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Visual Identity Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

This assessment task introduces and working with principles of Graphic Design in the following ways: a deliberate, abductive design process; naming and visual identity development; and production of a basic style guide document. The assessment task affords opportunity to extend the application of the identity into an identity system, which is a more advanced format than the traditional static, single logo. The assessment task asks students to identify an organization type from one of several possible sectors, investigate the demographic to which the organization is targeted, and then follow a design process that leads to the creation of an identity and application to various formats.

This assessment task includes a mid-point presentation (Part A) in Week 3, and Part B which is your final presentation and project deliverables submitted to the University's online system (Moodle) in Week 5.

In order to complete this task students will need to have the following proficiencies: Drawing/sketching skills, academic research and writing skills, working with material/media, capturing a digital image, scanning and image file management, basic skills in Adobe software, particularly InDesign, Illustrator, and to a lesser degree, Photoshop.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0c9aa133dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619bf","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"489aa133dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619c2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"849aa133dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619c5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b38aa133dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ba","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"cc9aa133dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619bc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b38aa133dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ac","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Event Brand Identity Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

This project allows for the extension of knowledge of visual identity design developed in the previous assessment task through the creation of brand and event identity for a cultural event. Students will focus on typography and image development, and will extend their knowledge of colour, layout and general design principles. Students will communicate the application of the event identity through a range of media promoting a variety of sub-events. Submission will include a visual and verbal presentation, as well as a curated visual journal and a design rationale

In order to complete this task students will be required to have the following proficiencies: Drawing/sketching skills, academic research and writing skills, working with material/media, capturing a digital image, scanning and image file management, basic skills in Adobe software, particularly InDesign, Illustrator, and Photoshop.

contentlets.keywords: design studies,visual identity,brand design,logo design,graphics media
contentlets.description: This course explores the principles of visual communication through a range of brand design projects. By observing the branded identities of people, places, and services as well as products and organisations, you will develop and present designed identities for print, screen, and outdoor application. Reflection on the contextual factors that impact the interpretation and use of the identity will inform its development.
contentlets.title: Introduction to Graphics Media

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"SDES9761","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES9761 - Contemporary Typography","description":"

Contemporary graphic design is a constant state of flux. As a result, the ways in which we develop, consider and use typefaces is more diverse than ever. This course will explore methods by which you can generate and formalise a typeface using originality in research techniques. The course will help you understand how that typeface can then be integrated into contemporary print and screen applications. This course also gives you the opportunity to reconsider issues of legibility and readability in historical and contemporary typographic practices.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"d78aa133dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96197d","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Designing a Typeface","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

The purpose of this assessment task is to create a set of unique roman alphabetical type forms. Using first-hand visual research as well as reference to typographic theory, students will create an initial limited set of experimental type forms. Students will then extend them into a full set of letters that will be used for the titles of the three book covers in Assessment Task 2. The focus will be on creating original concepts, and understanding theory specific to typeface design, such as individual characteristics, consistency and legibility.

In order to complete this task you will need to have the following proficiencies:

-        Drawing/sketching skills, working with material/media, graphic investigation, capturing a digital image, scanning and image file management.

-        Basic to intermediate skills in Adobe: InDesign, Illustrator, Photoshop, Acrobat.

-        Academic research and writing skills

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"038aa133dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961962","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"538aa133dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961974","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"9f8aa133dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961976","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"db8aa133dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961979","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7a8aa133dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961947","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Typography in Publication and Screen Design","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

Assessment Task 2 will focus on applying the typeface created in the previous assessment task to a series of three book cover designs. Students will be asked to design the front and back covers with spine, as well as some specific pages for the internal parts of the books. The task will involve generating additional content—text or image—to combine with the desaigned typeface to produce a compelling narrative on each book cover. This project will introduce or reinforce an understanding of layout and grids as a critical element of graphic design. As well, the assignment builds the concept of consistency in aesthetic style across different types. Students will also produce a screen-based element aimed at promoting the book series to a range of audiences.

In order to complete this task students will need to have the following proficiencies:

-        Drawing/sketching skills, working with material/media, graphic investigation, capturing a digital image, scanning and image file management.

-        Basic to intermediate skills in Adobe: InDesign, Illustrator, Photoshop and Acrobat.

-        Academic research and writing skills

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"SDES9762","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[{"dependent_type":{"label":null,"value":null},"ai_cl_id":{"value":"SDES9762","cl_id":"398a6133dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ba","key":"code"},"association_type":{"label":"Equivalents","value":"9"},"association_desc":"","associated_ai_cl_id":{"value":"SDES9207","cl_id":"c9ef0eebdbf59850eb6b147a3a96191f","key":"code"},"cl_id":"4cfb5948db02d850358b403c3a961965","assoc_credit_points":"6","assoc_active":"false","assoc_title":"Design Studio: Graphics/Media 2","assoc_cl_id":"c9ef0eebdbf59850eb6b147a3a96191f","assoc_short_title":"SDES9207 - Design Studio: Graphics/Media 2","assoc_campus":null,"assoc_url":"/postgraduate/courses/2021/SDES9207","assoc_class":"Course","assoc_award_titles":null,"assoc_state":"inactive","assoc_award_single":"","assoc_code":"SDES9207","assoc_class_translated_subjects":"Course","assoc_faculty":"Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SDES9762 - Graphic Design for the Web","description":"

This course will take you through processes of researching, planning and designing the 'architecture' of a website. You will learn how the planning detail and graphic design of web-pages directly relates to the way users interact and experience websites, ultimately determining their effectiveness and functionality. Based on the 'architecture' plan for the website, you will complete production of graphic designs for a series of web-pages.

Assessment tasks require you to plan and apply your graphic skills to the design of websites that provide an internet presence for non-profit agencies and people in need. By the end of the course you will have completed the graphic design of an entire website, and have the conceptual and practical skills, and confidence, to develop further web designs.

You will need at least a basic understanding of Adobe Photoshop before enrolling in this course. Students do not need any knowledge of web-programming. In addition, to undertake this course students should have completed, or have, at least one of the following:


  • Knowledge and skills in graphics media design and processes or equivalent
  • 48 UOC in Design related courses
  • SDES6740 Introduction to Graphics Media

In this project students will research and analyse selected current websites, and learn the fundamentals in information design for web design. Students will apply findings to the design and development of a website template.

Please note: Graphic Design for the Web, is an advanced course -  Photoshops and Illustrator skills are required. If you have never used Photoshop and Illustrator skills, it is your responsibility to undertake basic training in the interface on Lynda.com.

contentlets.description:
This course will take you through processes of researching, planning and designing the 'architecture' of a website. You will learn how the planning detail and graphic design of web-pages directly relates to the way users interact and experience websites, ultimately determining their effectiveness and functionality. Based on the 'architecture' plan for the website, you will complete production of graphic designs for a series of web-pages.

Assessment tasks require you to plan and apply your graphic skills to the design of websites that provide an internet presence for non-profit agencies and people in need. By the end of the course you will have completed the graphic design of an entire website, and have the conceptual and practical skills, and confidence, to develop further web designs.

You will need at least a basic understanding of Adobe Photoshop before enrolling in this course. Students do not need any knowledge of web-programming. In addition, to undertake this course students should have completed, or have, at least one of the following:

  • Knowledge and skills in graphics media design and processes or equivalent
